projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts encodes the edition of each play by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine in TEI Simple. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptionss and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

castGroup.castItem: Ladies, Eunuchs, Captains, Officers, Soldiers, Attendants, Servants (Lamprius, Rannius, Lucillius: mute characters named in the opening stage direction to 1.2)

div.head: Scene 1

sp.speaker: PHILO
sp.l: Nay, but this dotage of our general’s
O’erflows the measure. Those his goodly eyes,
That o’er the files and musters of the war
Have glowed like plated Mars, now bend, now turn
The office and devotion of their view
Upon a tawny front. His captain’s heart,
Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst
The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper
And is become the bellows and the fan
To cool a gypsy’s lust.
sp.stage: Flourish. Enter Antony, Cleopatra, her Ladies, the Train, with Eunuchs fanning her.
sp.l: Look where they come.
Take but good note, and you shall see in him
The triple pillar of the world transformed
Into a strumpet’s fool. Behold and see.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: If it be love indeed, tell me how much.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: There’s beggary in the love that can be reckoned.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I’ll set a bourn how far to be beloved.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new Earth.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: News, my good lord, from Rome.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Grates me, the sum.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Nay, hear them, Antony.
Fulvia perchance is angry. Or who knows
If the scarce-bearded Caesar have not sent
His powerful mandate to you: “ Do this, or this;
Take in that kingdom, and enfranchise that.
Perform ’t, or else we damn thee.”

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: How, my love?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Perchance? Nay, and most like.
You must not stay here longer; your dismission
Is come from Caesar. Therefore hear it, Antony.
Where’s Fulvia’s process? Caesar’s, I would say— both?
Call in the messengers. As I am Egypt’s queen,
Thou blushest, Antony, and that blood of thine
Is Caesar’s homager; else so thy cheek pays shame
When shrill-tongued Fulvia scolds. The messengers!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Let Rome in Tiber melt and the wide arch
Of the ranged empire fall. Here is my space.
Kingdoms are clay. Our dungy earth alike
Feeds beast as man. The nobleness of life
Is to do thus; when such a mutual pair
And such a twain can do ’t, in which I bind,
On pain of punishment, the world to weet
We stand up peerless.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Excellent falsehood!
Why did he marry Fulvia and not love her?
I’ll seem the fool I am not. Antony
Will be himself.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: But stirred by Cleopatra.
Now for the love of Love and her soft hours,
Let’s not confound the time with conference harsh.
There’s not a minute of our lives should stretch
Without some pleasure now. What sport tonight?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Hear the ambassadors.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Fie, wrangling queen,
Whom everything becomes— to chide, to laugh,
To weep; whose every passion fully strives
To make itself, in thee, fair and admired!
No messenger but thine, and all alone
Tonight we’ll wander through the streets and note
The qualities of people. Come, my queen,
Last night you did desire it. To the Messenger. Speak not to us.

div.stage: Antony and Cleopatra exit with the Train.

sp.speaker: DEMETRIUS
sp.l: Is Caesar with Antonius prized so slight?

sp.speaker: PHILO
sp.l: Sir, sometimes when he is not Antony
He comes too short of that great property
Which still should go with Antony.

sp.speaker: DEMETRIUS
sp.l: I am full sorry
That he approves the common liar who
Thus speaks of him at Rome; but I will hope
Of better deeds tomorrow. Rest you happy!

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Enobarbus, Lamprius, a Soothsayer, Rannius, Lucillius, Charmian, Iras, Mardian the Eunuch, Alexas, and Servants.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p:
Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything
Alexas, almost most absolute Alexas, where’s the
soothsayer that you praised so to th’ Queen? O, that
I knew this husband which you say must charge
his horns with garlands!

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.p: Soothsayer!

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.p: Your will?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Is this the man?— Is ’t you, sir, that know things?

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.l: In nature’s infinite book of secrecy
A little I can read.

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: Show him your hand.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Bring in the banquet quickly, wine enough
Cleopatra’s health to drink.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.stage: , giving her hand to the Soothsayer
sp.p:
Good sir,
give me good fortune.

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.p: I make not, but foresee.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Pray then, foresee me one.

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.l: You shall be yet far fairer than you are.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: He means in flesh.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.p: No, you shall paint when you are old.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Wrinkles forbid!

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.p: Vex not his prescience. Be attentive.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Hush.

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.l: You shall be more beloving than beloved.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: I had rather heat my liver with drinking.

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.p: Nay, hear him.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p:
Good now, some excellent fortune! Let me
be married to three kings in a forenoon and widow
them all. Let me have a child at fifty to whom Herod
of Jewry may do homage. Find me to marry me
with Octavius Caesar, and companion me with my
mistress.

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.l: You shall outlive the lady whom you serve.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: O, excellent! I love long life better than figs.

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.l: You have seen and proved a fairer former fortune
Than that which is to approach.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p:
Then belike my children shall have no
names. Prithee, how many boys and wenches must
I have?

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.l: If every of your wishes had a womb,
And fertile every wish, a million.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Out, fool! I forgive thee for a witch.

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.p:
You think none but your sheets are privy to
your wishes.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Nay, come. Tell Iras hers.

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.p: We’ll know all our fortunes.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Mine, and most of our fortunes tonight,
shall be— drunk to bed.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.stage: , giving her hand to the Soothsayer
sp.p:
There’s a palm
presages chastity, if nothing else.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p:
E’en as the o’erflowing Nilus presageth
famine.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.p: Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p:
Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication,
I cannot scratch mine ear.— Prithee
tell her but a workaday fortune.

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.p: Your fortunes are alike.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.p: But how, but how? Give me particulars.

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.p: I have said.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.p: Am I not an inch of fortune better than she?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p:
Well, if you were but an inch of fortune
better than I, where would you choose it?

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.p: Not in my husband’s nose.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p:
Our worser thoughts heavens mend. Alexas—
come, his fortune, his fortune! O, let him marry a
woman that cannot go, sweet Isis, I beseech thee, and
let her die, too, and give him a worse, and let worse
follow worse, till the worst of all follow him laughing
to his grave, fiftyfold a cuckold. Good Isis, hear me
this prayer, though thou deny me a matter of more
weight, good Isis, I beseech thee!

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.p:
Amen, dear goddess, hear that prayer of the
people. For, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome
man loose-wived, so it is a deadly sorrow to
behold a foul knave uncuckolded. Therefore, dear
Isis, keep decorum and fortune him accordingly.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.p:
Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make me a
cuckold, they would make themselves whores but
they’d do ’t.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: Hush, here comes Antony.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Not he. The Queen.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Saw you my lord?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: No, lady.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Was he not here?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: No, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: He was disposed to mirth, but on the sudden
A Roman thought hath struck him.— Enobarbus!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Madam?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Seek him and bring him hither.— Where’s Alexas?

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: Here at your service. My lord approaches.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: We will not look upon him. Go with us.

div.stage: All but Antony and the Messenger exit.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Against my brother Lucius?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Ay.
But soon that war had end, and the time’s state
Made friends of them, jointing their force ’gainst Caesar,
Whose better issue in the war from Italy
Upon the first encounter drave them.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Well, what worst?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: The nature of bad news infects the teller.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: When it concerns the fool or coward. On.
Things that are past are done, with me. ’Tis thus:
Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death,
I hear him as he flattered.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Labienus—
This is stiff news— hath with his Parthian force
Extended Asia: from Euphrates
His conquering banner shook, from Syria
To Lydia and to Ionia,
Whilst—

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: “ Antony,” thou wouldst say?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: O, my lord!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Speak to me home; mince not the general tongue.
Name Cleopatra as she is called in Rome;
Rail thou in Fulvia’s phrase, and taunt my faults
With such full license as both truth and malice
Have power to utter. O, then we bring forth weeds
When our quick winds lie still, and our ills told us
Is as our earing. Fare thee well awhile.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: At your noble pleasure.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: From Sicyon how the news? Speak there.

sp.speaker: SECOND MESSENGER
sp.l: The man from Sicyon—

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Is there such an one?

sp.speaker: SECOND MESSENGER
sp.l: He stays upon your will.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Let him appear.
These strong Egyptian fetters I must break,
Or lose myself in dotage.
sp.stage: Enter another Messenger with a letter.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: THIRD MESSENGER
sp.l: Fulvia thy wife is dead.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Where died she?

sp.speaker: THIRD MESSENGER
sp.l: In Sicyon.
Her length of sickness, with what else more serious
Importeth thee to know, this bears.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Forbear me.
There’s a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it.
What our contempts doth often hurl from us,
We wish it ours again. The present pleasure,
By revolution lowering, does become
The opposite of itself. She’s good, being gone.
The hand could pluck her back that shoved her on.
I must from this enchanting queen break off.
Ten thousand harms more than the ills I know
My idleness doth hatch.— How now, Enobarbus!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: What’s your pleasure, sir?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: I must with haste from hence.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Why then we kill all our women. We see
how mortal an unkindness is to them. If they suffer
our departure, death’s the word.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: I must be gone.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Under a compelling occasion, let women
die. It were pity to cast them away for nothing,
though between them and a great cause, they
should be esteemed nothing. Cleopatra, catching
but the least noise of this, dies instantly. I have seen
her die twenty times upon far poorer moment. I do
think there is mettle in death which commits some
loving act upon her, she hath such a celerity in
dying.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: She is cunning past man’s thought.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Alack, sir, no, her passions are made of
nothing but the finest part of pure love. We cannot
call her winds and waters sighs and tears; they are
greater storms and tempests than almanacs can
report. This cannot be cunning in her; if it be, she
makes a shower of rain as well as Jove.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: Would I had never seen her!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
O, sir, you had then left unseen a wonderful
piece of work, which not to have been blest
withal would have discredited your travel.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: Fulvia is dead.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: Fulvia is dead.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: Fulvia?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: Dead.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice.
When it pleaseth their deities to take the wife of a
man from him, it shows to man the tailors of the
Earth; comforting therein, that when old robes are
worn out, there are members to make new. If there
were no more women but Fulvia, then had you
indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented. This grief
is crowned with consolation; your old smock brings
forth a new petticoat, and indeed the tears live in an
onion that should water this sorrow.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: The business she hath broachèd in the state
Cannot endure my absence.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
And the business you have broached here
cannot be without you, especially that of Cleopatra’s,
which wholly depends on your abode.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: No more light answers. Let our officers
Have notice what we purpose. I shall break
The cause of our expedience to the Queen
And get her leave to part. For not alone
The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches,
Do strongly speak to us, but the letters too
Of many our contriving friends in Rome
Petition us at home. Sextus Pompeius
Hath given the dare to Caesar and commands
The empire of the sea. Our slippery people,
Whose love is never linked to the deserver
Till his deserts are past, begin to throw
Pompey the Great and all his dignities
Upon his son, who— high in name and power,
Higher than both in blood and life— stands up
For the main soldier; whose quality, going on,
The sides o’ th’ world may danger. Much is breeding
Which, like the courser’s hair, hath yet but life
And not a serpent’s poison. Say our pleasure,
To such whose place is under us, requires
Our quick remove from hence.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: I shall do ’t.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Alexas, and Iras.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: I did not see him since.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: See where he is, who’s with him, what he does.
I did not send you. If you find him sad,
Say I am dancing; if in mirth, report
That I am sudden sick. Quick, and return.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Madam, methinks, if you did love him dearly,
You do not hold the method to enforce
The like from him.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What should I do I do not?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: In each thing give him way; cross him in nothing.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Thou teachest like a fool: the way to lose him.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Tempt him not so too far. I wish, forbear.
In time we hate that which we often fear.
But here comes Antony.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I am sick and sullen.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Help me away, dear Charmian! I shall fall.
It cannot be thus long; the sides of nature
Will not sustain it.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Now, my dearest queen—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Pray you stand farther from me.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: What’s the matter?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I know by that same eye there’s some good news.
What, says the married woman you may go?
Would she had never given you leave to come.
Let her not say ’tis I that keep you here.
I have no power upon you. Hers you are.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: The gods best know—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, never was there queen
So mightily betrayed! Yet at the first
I saw the treasons planted.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Cleopatra—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Why should I think you can be mine, and true—
Though you in swearing shake the thronèd gods—
Who have been false to Fulvia? Riotous madness,
To be entangled with those mouth-made vows
Which break themselves in swearing!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Most sweet queen—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Nay, pray you seek no color for your going,
But bid farewell and go. When you sued staying,
Then was the time for words. No going then!
Eternity was in our lips and eyes,
Bliss in our brows’ bent; none our parts so poor
But was a race of heaven. They are so still,
Or thou, the greatest soldier of the world,
Art turned the greatest liar.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: How now, lady?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I would I had thy inches. Thou shouldst know
There were a heart in Egypt.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Hear me, queen:
The strong necessity of time commands
Our services awhile, but my full heart
Remains in use with you. Our Italy
Shines o’er with civil swords; Sextus Pompeius
Makes his approaches to the port of Rome;
Equality of two domestic powers
Breed scrupulous faction; the hated grown to strength
Are newly grown to love; the condemned Pompey,
Rich in his father’s honor, creeps apace
Into the hearts of such as have not thrived
Upon the present state, whose numbers threaten;
And quietness, grown sick of rest, would purge
By any desperate change. My more particular,
And that which most with you should safe my going,
Is Fulvia’s death.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Though age from folly could not give me freedom,
It does from childishness. Can Fulvia die?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: She’s dead, my queen.
Look here, and at thy sovereign leisure read
The garboils she awaked; at the last, best,
See when and where she died.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, most false love!
Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill
With sorrowful water? Now I see, I see,
In Fulvia’s death, how mine received shall be.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Quarrel no more, but be prepared to know
The purposes I bear, which are or cease
As you shall give th’ advice. By the fire
That quickens Nilus’ slime, I go from hence
Thy soldier, servant, making peace or war
As thou affects.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Cut my lace, Charmian, come!
But let it be; I am quickly ill and well;
So Antony loves.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: My precious queen, forbear,
And give true evidence to his love, which stands
An honorable trial.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: So Fulvia told me.
I prithee turn aside and weep for her,
Then bid adieu to me, and say the tears
Belong to Egypt. Good now, play one scene
Of excellent dissembling, and let it look
Like perfect honor.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: You’ll heat my blood. No more!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: You can do better yet, but this is meetly.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Now by my sword—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: And target. Still he mends.
But this is not the best. Look, prithee, Charmian,
How this Herculean Roman does become
The carriage of his chafe.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I’ll leave you, lady.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Courteous lord, one word.
Sir, you and I must part, but that’s not it;
Sir, you and I have loved, but there’s not it;
That you know well. Something it is I would—
O, my oblivion is a very Antony,
And I am all forgotten.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: But that your Royalty
Holds idleness your subject, I should take you
For idleness itself.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: ’Tis sweating labor
To bear such idleness so near the heart
As Cleopatra this. But, sir, forgive me,
Since my becomings kill me when they do not
Eye well to you. Your honor calls you hence;
Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly,
And all the gods go with you. Upon your sword
Sit laurel victory, and smooth success
Be strewed before your feet.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Let us go. Come.
Our separation so abides and flies
That thou, residing here, goes yet with me,
And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee.
Away!

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Octavius Caesar, reading a letter, Lepidus, and their Train.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: You may see, Lepidus, and henceforth know,
It is not Caesar’s natural vice to hate
Our great competitor. From Alexandria
This is the news: he fishes, drinks, and wastes
The lamps of night in revel, is not more manlike
Than Cleopatra, nor the queen of Ptolemy
More womanly than he; hardly gave audience, or
Vouchsafed to think he had partners. You shall find there
A man who is th’ abstract of all faults
That all men follow.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: I must not think there are
Evils enough to darken all his goodness.
His faults in him seem as the spots of heaven,
More fiery by night’s blackness, hereditary
Rather than purchased, what he cannot change
Than what he chooses.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: You are too indulgent. Let’s grant it is not
Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy,
To give a kingdom for a mirth, to sit
And keep the turn of tippling with a slave,
To reel the streets at noon and stand the buffet
With knaves that smells of sweat. Say this becomes him—
As his composure must be rare indeed
Whom these things cannot blemish— yet must Antony
No way excuse his foils when we do bear
So great weight in his lightness. If he filled
His vacancy with his voluptuousness,
Full surfeits and the dryness of his bones
Call on him for ’t. But to confound such time
That drums him from his sport and speaks as loud
As his own state and ours, ’tis to be chid
As we rate boys who, being mature in knowledge,
Pawn their experience to their present pleasure
And so rebel to judgment.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Here’s more news.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Thy biddings have been done, and every hour,
Most noble Caesar, shalt thou have report
How ’tis abroad. Pompey is strong at sea,
And it appears he is beloved of those
That only have feared Caesar. To the ports
The discontents repair, and men’s reports
Give him much wronged.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I should have known no less.
It hath been taught us from the primal state
That he which is was wished until he were,
And the ebbed man, ne’er loved till ne’er worth love,
Comes feared by being lacked. This common body,
Like to a vagabond flag upon the stream,
Goes to and back, lackeying the varying tide
To rot itself with motion.

sp.speaker: SECOND MESSENGER
sp.l: Caesar, I bring thee word
Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates,
Makes the sea serve them, which they ear and wound
With keels of every kind. Many hot inroads
They make in Italy— the borders maritime
Lack blood to think on ’t— and flush youth revolt.
No vessel can peep forth but ’tis as soon
Taken as seen, for Pompey’s name strikes more
Than could his war resisted.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Antony,
Leave thy lascivious wassails. When thou once
Was beaten from Modena, where thou slew’st
Hirsius and Pansa, consuls, at thy heel
Did famine follow, whom thou fought’st against,
Though daintily brought up, with patience more
Than savages could suffer. Thou didst drink
The stale of horses and the gilded puddle
Which beasts would cough at. Thy palate then did deign
The roughest berry on the rudest hedge.
Yea, like the stag when snow the pasture sheets,
The barks of trees thou browsèd. On the Alps
It is reported thou didst eat strange flesh
Which some did die to look on. And all this—
It wounds thine honor that I speak it now—
Was borne so like a soldier that thy cheek
So much as lanked not.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: ’Tis pity of him.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Let his shames quickly
Drive him to Rome. ’Tis time we twain
Did show ourselves i’ th’ field, and to that end
Assemble we immediate council. Pompey
Thrives in our idleness.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Tomorrow, Caesar,
I shall be furnished to inform you rightly
Both what by sea and land I can be able
To front this present time.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Till which encounter,
It is my business too. Farewell.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Farewell, my lord. What you shall know meantime
Of stirs abroad, I shall beseech you, sir,
To let me be partaker.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Doubt not, sir. I knew it for my bond.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Mardian.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Charmian!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Ha, ha! Give me to drink mandragora.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.p: Why, madam?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: That I might sleep out this great gap of time
My Antony is away.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: You think of him too much.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, ’tis treason!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Madam, I trust not so.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Thou, eunuch Mardian!

sp.speaker: MARDIAN
sp.l: What’s your Highness’ pleasure?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Not now to hear thee sing. I take no pleasure
In aught an eunuch has. ’Tis well for thee
That, being unseminared, thy freer thoughts
May not fly forth of Egypt. Hast thou affections?

sp.speaker: MARDIAN
sp.l: Yes, gracious madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Indeed?

sp.speaker: MARDIAN
sp.l: Not in deed, madam, for I can do nothing
But what indeed is honest to be done.
Yet have I fierce affections, and think
What Venus did with Mars.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, Charmian,
Where think’st thou he is now? Stands he, or sits he?
Or does he walk? Or is he on his horse?
O happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony!
Do bravely, horse, for wot’st thou whom thou mov’st?
The demi-Atlas of this Earth, the arm
And burgonet of men. He’s speaking now,
Or murmuring “ Where’s my serpent of old Nile?”
For so he calls me. Now I feed myself
With most delicious poison. Think on me
That am with Phoebus’ amorous pinches black,
And wrinkled deep in time? Broad-fronted Caesar,
When thou wast here above the ground, I was
A morsel for a monarch. And great Pompey
Would stand and make his eyes grow in my brow;
There would he anchor his aspect, and die
With looking on his life.

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: Sovereign of Egypt, hail!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: How much unlike art thou Mark Antony!
Yet coming from him, that great med’cine hath
With his tinct gilded thee.
How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: Last thing he did, dear queen,
He kissed— the last of many doubled kisses—
This orient pearl. His speech sticks in my heart.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Mine ear must pluck it thence.

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: “ Good friend,” quoth he,
“ Say the firm Roman to great Egypt sends
This treasure of an oyster; at whose foot,
To mend the petty present, I will piece
Her opulent throne with kingdoms. All the East,
Say thou, shall call her mistress.” So he nodded
And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt steed,
Who neighed so high that what I would have spoke
Was beastly dumbed by him.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What, was he sad, or merry?

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: Like to the time o’ th’ year between th’ extremes
Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merry.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, well-divided disposition!— Note him,
Note him, good Charmian, ’tis the man! But note him:
He was not sad, for he would shine on those
That make their looks by his; he was not merry,
Which seemed to tell them his remembrance lay
In Egypt with his joy; but between both.
O, heavenly mingle!— Be’st thou sad or merry,
The violence of either thee becomes,
So does it no man’s else.— Met’st thou my posts?

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: Ay, madam, twenty several messengers.
Why do you send so thick?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Who’s born that day
When I forget to send to Antony
Shall die a beggar.— Ink and paper, Charmian.—
Welcome, my good Alexas.— Did I, Charmian,
Ever love Caesar so?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: O, that brave Caesar!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Be choked with such another emphasis!
Say “ the brave Antony.”

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: The valiant Caesar!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: By Isis, I will give thee bloody teeth
If thou with Caesar paragon again
My man of men.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: By your most gracious pardon,
I sing but after you.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: My salad days,
When I was green in judgment, cold in blood,
To say as I said then. But come, away,
Get me ink and paper.
He shall have every day a several greeting,
Or I’ll unpeople Egypt.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Pompey, Menecrates, and Menas, in warlike manner.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: If the great gods be just, they shall assist
The deeds of justest men.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Know, worthy Pompey,
That what they do delay they not deny.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Whiles we are suitors to their throne, decays
The thing we sue for.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: We, ignorant of ourselves,
Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers
Deny us for our good; so find we profit
By losing of our prayers.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: I shall do well.
The people love me, and the sea is mine;
My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope
Says it will come to th’ full. Mark Antony
In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make
No wars without doors. Caesar gets money where
He loses hearts. Lepidus flatters both,
Of both is flattered; but he neither loves,
Nor either cares for him.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Caesar and Lepidus
Are in the field. A mighty strength they carry.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Where have you this? ’Tis false.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: From Silvius, sir.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: He dreams. I know they are in Rome together,
Looking for Antony. But all the charms of love,
Salt Cleopatra, soften thy wanned lip!
Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both;
Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts;
Keep his brain fuming. Epicurean cooks
Sharpen with cloyless sauce his appetite,
That sleep and feeding may prorogue his honor
Even till a Lethe’d dullness—
How now, Varrius?

sp.speaker: VARRIUS
sp.l: This is most certain that I shall deliver:
Mark Antony is every hour in Rome
Expected. Since he went from Egypt ’tis
A space for farther travel.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: I could have given less matter
A better ear.— Menas, I did not think
This amorous surfeiter would have donned his helm
For such a petty war. His soldiership
Is twice the other twain. But let us rear
The higher our opinion, that our stirring
Can from the lap of Egypt’s widow pluck
The ne’er lust-wearied Antony.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: I cannot hope
Caesar and Antony shall well greet together.
His wife that’s dead did trespasses to Caesar;
His brother warred upon him, although I think
Not moved by Antony.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: I know not, Menas,
How lesser enmities may give way to greater.
Were ’t not that we stand up against them all,
’Twere pregnant they should square between themselves,
For they have entertainèd cause enough
To draw their swords. But how the fear of us
May cement their divisions and bind up
The petty difference, we yet not know.
Be ’t as our gods will have ’t. It only stands
Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.
Come, Menas.

div.head: Scene 2

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Good Enobarbus, ’tis a worthy deed,
And shall become you well, to entreat your captain
To soft and gentle speech.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: I shall entreat him
To answer like himself. If Caesar move him,
Let Antony look over Caesar’s head
And speak as loud as Mars. By Jupiter,
Were I the wearer of Antonio’s beard,
I would not shave ’t today.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: ’Tis not a time for private stomaching.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Every time serves for the matter that is
then born in ’t.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: But small to greater matters must give way.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Not if the small come first.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Your speech is passion; but pray you stir
No embers up. Here comes the noble Antony.

div.stage: Enter, at one door, Antony and Ventidius.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: And yonder Caesar.

div.stage: Enter, at another door, Caesar, Maecenas, and Agrippa.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: If we compose well here, to Parthia.
Hark, Ventidius.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I do not know, Maecenas. Ask Agrippa.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Noble friends,
That which combined us was most great, and let not
A leaner action rend us. What’s amiss,
May it be gently heard. When we debate
Our trivial difference loud, we do commit
Murder in healing wounds. Then, noble partners,
The rather for I earnestly beseech,
Touch you the sourest points with sweetest terms,
Nor curstness grow to th’ matter.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: ’Tis spoken well.
Were we before our armies, and to fight,
I should do thus.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Welcome to Rome.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Thank you.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Sit.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Sit, sir.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Nay, then.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I learn you take things ill which are not so,
Or, being, concern you not.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I must be laughed at
If or for nothing or a little, I
Should say myself offended, and with you
Chiefly i’ th’ world; more laughed at, that I should
Once name you derogately when to sound your name
It not concerned me.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: My being in Egypt, Caesar, what was ’t to you?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: No more than my residing here at Rome
Might be to you in Egypt. Yet if you there
Did practice on my state, your being in Egypt
Might be my question.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: How intend you, practiced?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: You may be pleased to catch at mine intent
By what did here befall me. Your wife and brother
Made wars upon me, and their contestation
Was theme for you; you were the word of war.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: You do mistake your business. My brother never
Did urge me in his act. I did inquire it,
And have my learning from some true reports
That drew their swords with you. Did he not rather
Discredit my authority with yours,
And make the wars alike against my stomach,
Having alike your cause? Of this my letters
Before did satisfy you. If you’ll patch a quarrel,
As matter whole you have to make it with,
It must not be with this.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: You praise yourself
By laying defects of judgment to me; but
You patched up your excuses.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Not so, not so.
I know you could not lack— I am certain on ’t—
Very necessity of this thought, that I,
Your partner in the cause ’gainst which he fought,
Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars
Which fronted mine own peace. As for my wife,
I would you had her spirit in such another.
The third o’ th’ world is yours, which with a snaffle
You may pace easy, but not such a wife.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Would we had all such wives, that the men
might go to wars with the women!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: So much uncurbable, her garboils, Caesar,
Made out of her impatience— which not wanted
Shrewdness of policy too— I grieving grant
Did you too much disquiet. For that you must
But say I could not help it.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I wrote to you
When rioting in Alexandria; you
Did pocket up my letters, and with taunts
Did gibe my missive out of audience.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Sir,
He fell upon me ere admitted, then;
Three kings I had newly feasted, and did want
Of what I was i’ th’ morning. But next day
I told him of myself, which was as much
As to have asked him pardon. Let this fellow
Be nothing of our strife; if we contend,
Out of our question wipe him.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: You have broken
The article of your oath, which you shall never
Have tongue to charge me with.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Soft, Caesar!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: No, Lepidus, let him speak.
The honor is sacred which he talks on now,
Supposing that I lacked it.— But on, Caesar:
The article of my oath?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: To lend me arms and aid when I required them,
The which you both denied.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Neglected, rather;
And then when poisoned hours had bound me up
From mine own knowledge. As nearly as I may
I’ll play the penitent to you. But mine honesty
Shall not make poor my greatness, nor my power
Work without it. Truth is that Fulvia,
To have me out of Egypt, made wars here,
For which myself, the ignorant motive, do
So far ask pardon as befits mine honor
To stoop in such a case.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: ’Tis noble spoken.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: If it might please you to enforce no further
The griefs between you, to forget them quite
Were to remember that the present need
Speaks to atone you.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Worthily spoken, Maecenas.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Or, if you borrow one another’s love for
the instant, you may, when you hear no more words
of Pompey, return it again. You shall have time to
wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Thou art a soldier only. Speak no more.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
That truth should be silent I had almost
forgot.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: You wrong this presence; therefore speak no more.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: Go to, then. Your considerate stone.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I do not much dislike the matter, but
The manner of his speech; for ’t cannot be
We shall remain in friendship, our conditions
So diff’ring in their acts. Yet if I knew
What hoop should hold us staunch, from edge to edge
O’ th’ world I would pursue it.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Give me leave, Caesar.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Speak, Agrippa.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Thou hast a sister by the mother’s side,
Admired Octavia. Great Mark Antony
Is now a widower.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Say not so, Agrippa.
If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof
Were well deserved of rashness.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I am not married, Caesar. Let me hear
Agrippa further speak.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: To hold you in perpetual amity,
To make you brothers, and to knit your hearts
With an unslipping knot, take Antony
Octavia to his wife, whose beauty claims
No worse a husband than the best of men;
Whose virtue and whose general graces speak
That which none else can utter. By this marriage
All little jealousies, which now seem great,
And all great fears, which now import their dangers,
Would then be nothing. Truths would be tales,
Where now half-tales be truths. Her love to both
Would each to other and all loves to both
Draw after her. Pardon what I have spoke,
For ’tis a studied, not a present thought,
By duty ruminated.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Will Caesar speak?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Not till he hears how Antony is touched
With what is spoke already.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: What power is in Agrippa,
If I would say “ Agrippa, be it so,”
To make this good?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: The power of Caesar, and
His power unto Octavia.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: May I never
To this good purpose, that so fairly shows,
Dream of impediment. Let me have thy hand.
Further this act of grace; and from this hour
The heart of brothers govern in our loves
And sway our great designs.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: There’s my hand.
A sister I bequeath you whom no brother
Did ever love so dearly. Let her live
To join our kingdoms and our hearts; and never
Fly off our loves again.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Happily, amen!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I did not think to draw my sword ’gainst Pompey,
For he hath laid strange courtesies and great
Of late upon me. I must thank him only,
Lest my remembrance suffer ill report;
At heel of that, defy him.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Time calls upon ’s.
Of us must Pompey presently be sought,
Or else he seeks out us.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Where lies he?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: About the Mount Misena.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: What is his strength by land?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Great and increasing;
But by sea he is an absolute master.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: So is the fame.
Would we had spoke together. Haste we for it.
Yet, ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we
The business we have talked of.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: With most gladness,
And do invite you to my sister’s view,
Whither straight I’ll lead you.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Let us, Lepidus, not lack your company.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Noble Antony, not sickness should detain me.

div.stage: Flourish. All but Enobarbus, Agrippa, and Maecenas exit.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.p: Welcome from Egypt, sir.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Half the heart of Caesar, worthy
Maecenas!— My honorable friend Agrippa!

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.p: Good Enobarbus!

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.p:
We have cause to be glad that matters are so
well digested. You stayed well by ’t in Egypt.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Ay, sir, we did sleep day out of countenance
and made the night light with drinking.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.p:
Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast,
and but twelve persons there. Is this true?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
This was but as a fly by an eagle. We had
much more monstrous matter of feast, which worthily
deserved noting.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.p:
She’s a most triumphant lady, if report be
square to her.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
When she first met Mark Antony, she
pursed up his heart upon the river of Cydnus.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.p:
There she appeared indeed, or my reporter
devised well for her.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: I will tell you.
The barge she sat in like a burnished throne
Burned on the water. The poop was beaten gold,
Purple the sails, and so perfumed that
The winds were lovesick with them. The oars were silver,
Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made
The water which they beat to follow faster,
As amorous of their strokes. For her own person,
It beggared all description: she did lie
In her pavilion— cloth-of-gold, of tissue—
O’erpicturing that Venus where we see
The fancy outwork nature. On each side her
Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids,
With divers-colored fans, whose wind did seem
To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool,
And what they undid did.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: O, rare for Antony!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Her gentlewomen, like the Nereides,
So many mermaids, tended her i’ th’ eyes,
And made their bends adornings. At the helm
A seeming mermaid steers. The silken tackle
Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands
That yarely frame the office. From the barge
A strange invisible perfume hits the sense
Of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast
Her people out upon her; and Antony,
Enthroned i’ th’ market-place, did sit alone,
Whistling to th’ air, which but for vacancy
Had gone to gaze on Cleopatra too
And made a gap in nature.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Rare Egyptian!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Upon her landing, Antony sent to her,
Invited her to supper. She replied
It should be better he became her guest,
Which she entreated. Our courteous Antony,
Whom ne’er the word of “ No” woman heard speak,
Being barbered ten times o’er, goes to the feast,
And for his ordinary pays his heart
For what his eyes eat only.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Royal wench!
She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed;
He ploughed her, and she cropped.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: I saw her once
Hop forty paces through the public street,
And having lost her breath, she spoke and panted,
That she did make defect perfection,
And breathless pour breath forth.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: Now Antony must leave her utterly.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Never. He will not.
Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale
Her infinite variety. Other women cloy
The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry
Where most she satisfies. For vilest things
Become themselves in her, that the holy priests
Bless her when she is riggish.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: If beauty, wisdom, modesty can settle
The heart of Antony, Octavia is
A blessèd lottery to him.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Let us go.
Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest
Whilst you abide here.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Humbly, sir, I thank you.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Antony, Caesar; Octavia between them.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: The world and my great office will sometimes
Divide me from your bosom.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: All which time
Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers
To them for you.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Goodnight, sir.— My Octavia,
Read not my blemishes in the world’s report.
I have not kept my square, but that to come
Shall all be done by th’ rule. Good night, dear lady.—
Good night, sir.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Goodnight.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Now, sirrah, you do wish yourself in Egypt?

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.p:
Would I had never come from thence,
nor you thither.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: If you can, your reason?

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.p:
I see it in my motion, have it not in my
tongue. But yet hie you to Egypt again.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Say to me, whose fortunes shall rise higher,
Caesar’s or mine?

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.l: Caesar’s.
Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side.
Thy dæmon— that thy spirit which keeps thee— is
Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable,
Where Caesar’s is not. But near him, thy angel
Becomes afeard, as being o’erpowered. Therefore
Make space enough between you.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Speak this no more.

sp.speaker: SOOTHSAYER
sp.l: To none but thee; no more but when to thee.
If thou dost play with him at any game,
Thou art sure to lose; and of that natural luck
He beats thee ’gainst the odds. Thy luster thickens
When he shines by. I say again, thy spirit
Is all afraid to govern thee near him;
But he away, ’tis noble.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Get thee gone.
Say to Ventidius I would speak with him.
He shall to Parthia. Be it art or hap,
He hath spoken true. The very dice obey him,
And in our sports my better cunning faints
Under his chance. If we draw lots, he speeds;
His cocks do win the battle still of mine
When it is all to naught, and his quails ever
Beat mine, inhooped, at odds. I will to Egypt.
And though I make this marriage for my peace,
I’ th’ East my pleasure lies.
O, come, Ventidius.
You must to Parthia; your commission’s ready.
Follow me and receive ’t.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Trouble yourselves no further. Pray you hasten
Your generals after.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Sir, Mark Antony
Will e’en but kiss Octavia, and we’ll follow.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Till I shall see you in your soldiers’ dress,
Which will become you both, farewell.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: We shall,
As I conceive the journey, be at the Mount
Before you, Lepidus.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Your way is shorter;
My purposes do draw me much about.
You’ll win two days upon me.

sp.speaker: BOTH
sp.l: Sir, good success.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Farewell.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Give me some music— music, moody food
Of us that trade in love.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: The music, ho!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Let it alone. Let’s to billiards. Come, Charmian.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: My arm is sore. Best play with Mardian.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: As well a woman with an eunuch played
As with a woman.— Come, you’ll play with me, sir?

sp.speaker: MARDIAN
sp.l: As well as I can, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: And when good will is showed, though ’t come too short,
The actor may plead pardon. I’ll none now.
Give me mine angle; we’ll to th’ river. There,
My music playing far off, I will betray
Tawny-finned fishes. My bended hook shall pierce
Their slimy jaws, and as I draw them up
I’ll think them every one an Antony
And say “ Aha! You’re caught.”

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: ’Twas merry when
You wagered on your angling; when your diver
Did hang a salt fish on his hook, which he
With fervency drew up.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: That time?— O, times!—
I laughed him out of patience; and that night
I laughed him into patience; and next morn,
Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed,
Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst
I wore his sword Philippan.
O, from Italy!
Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears,
That long time have been barren.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Madam, madam—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Antonio’s dead! If thou say so, villain,
Thou kill’st thy mistress. But well and free,
If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here
My bluest veins to kiss, a hand that kings
Have lipped and trembled kissing.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: First, madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Why, there’s more gold. But sirrah, mark, we use
To say the dead are well. Bring it to that,
The gold I give thee will I melt and pour
Down thy ill-uttering throat.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Good madam, hear me.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Well, go to, I will.
But there’s no goodness in thy face— if Antony
Be free and healthful, so tart a favor
To trumpet such good tidings! If not well,
Thou shouldst come like a Fury crowned with snakes,
Not like a formal man.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Will ’t please you hear me?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak’st
Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well,
Or friends with Caesar or not captive to him,
I’ll set thee in a shower of gold and hail
Rich pearls upon thee.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Madam, he’s well.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Well said.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: And friends with Caesar.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Th’ art an honest man.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Make thee a fortune from me.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: But yet, madam—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I do not like “ But yet.” It does allay
The good precedence. Fie upon “ But yet.”
“ But yet” is as a jailer to bring forth
Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend,
Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear,
The good and bad together: he’s friends with Caesar,
In state of health, thou say’st, and, thou say’st, free.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Free, madam, no. I made no such report.
He’s bound unto Octavia.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: For what good turn?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: For the best turn i’ th’ bed.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I am pale, Charmian.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Madam, he’s married to Octavia.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: The most infectious pestilence upon thee!

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Good madam, patience!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What say you?
Hence, horrible villain, or I’ll spurn thine eyes
Like balls before me! I’ll unhair thy head!
sp.stage: She hales him up and down.
sp.l: Thou shalt be whipped with wire and stewed in brine,
Smarting in ling’ring pickle.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Gracious madam,
I that do bring the news made not the match.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Say ’tis not so, a province I will give thee
And make thy fortunes proud. The blow thou hadst
Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage,
And I will boot thee with what gift beside
Thy modesty can beg.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: He’s married, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Nay then, I’ll run.
What mean you, madam? I have made no fault.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Good madam, keep yourself within yourself.
The man is innocent.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Some innocents ’scape not the thunderbolt.
Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures
Turn all to serpents! Call the slave again.
Though I am mad, I will not bite him. Call!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: He is afeard to come.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I will not hurt him.
These hands do lack nobility that they strike
A meaner than myself, since I myself
Have given myself the cause.
Come hither, sir.
Though it be honest, it is never good
To bring bad news. Give to a gracious message
An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell
Themselves when they be felt.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: I have done my duty.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Is he married?
I cannot hate thee worser than I do
If thou again say “ yes.”

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: He’s married, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: The gods confound thee! Dost thou hold there still?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Should I lie, madam?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, I would thou didst,
So half my Egypt were submerged and made
A cistern for scaled snakes! Go, get thee hence.
Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me
Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: I crave your Highness’ pardon.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: He is married?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Take no offense that I would not offend you.
To punish me for what you make me do
Seems much unequal. He’s married to Octavia.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, that his fault should make a knave of thee
That art not what th’ art sure of! Get thee hence.
The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome
Are all too dear for me. Lie they upon thy hand,
And be undone by ’em!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Good your Highness, patience.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: In praising Antony, I have dispraised Caesar.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Many times, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I am paid for ’t now. Lead me from hence;
I faint. O, Iras, Charmian! ’Tis no matter.—
Go to the fellow, good Alexas. Bid him
Report the feature of Octavia, her years,
Her inclination; let him not leave out
The color of her hair. Bring me word quickly.
Let him forever go— let him not, Charmian.
Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon,
The other way ’s a Mars. ( To Mardian.) Bid you Alexas
Bring me word how tall she is.— Pity me, Charmian,
But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.

div.head: Scene 6
div.stage: Flourish. Enter Pompey and Menas at one door, with Drum and Trumpet; at another Caesar, Lepidus, Antony, Enobarbus, Maecenas, and Agrippa, with Soldiers marching.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Your hostages I have, so have you mine,
And we shall talk before we fight.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Most meet
That first we come to words, and therefore have we
Our written purposes before us sent,
Which if thou hast considered, let us know
If ’twill tie up thy discontented sword
And carry back to Sicily much tall youth
That else must perish here.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: To you all three,
The senators alone of this great world,
Chief factors for the gods: I do not know
Wherefore my father should revengers want,
Having a son and friends, since Julius Caesar,
Who at Philippi the good Brutus ghosted,
There saw you laboring for him. What was ’t
That moved pale Cassius to conspire? And what
Made the all-honored, honest, Roman Brutus,
With the armed rest, courtiers of beauteous freedom,
To drench the Capitol, but that they would
Have one man but a man? And that is it
Hath made me rig my navy, at whose burden
The angered ocean foams, with which I meant
To scourge th’ ingratitude that despiteful Rome
Cast on my noble father.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Take your time.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails.
We’ll speak with thee at sea. At land thou know’st
How much we do o’ercount thee.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: At land indeed
Thou dost o’ercount me of my father’s house;
But since the cuckoo builds not for himself,
Remain in ’t as thou mayst.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Be pleased to tell us—
For this is from the present— how you take
The offers we have sent you.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: There’s the point.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Which do not be entreated to, but weigh
What it is worth embraced.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: And what may follow
To try a larger fortune.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: You have made me offer
Of Sicily, Sardinia; and I must
Rid all the sea of pirates; then to send
Measures of wheat to Rome. This ’greed upon,
To part with unhacked edges and bear back
Our targes undinted.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: That’s our offer.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Know then
I came before you here a man prepared
To take this offer. But Mark Antony
Put me to some impatience.— Though I lose
The praise of it by telling, you must know
When Caesar and your brother were at blows,
Your mother came to Sicily and did find
Her welcome friendly.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I have heard it, Pompey,
And am well studied for a liberal thanks,
Which I do owe you.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Let me have your hand.
I did not think, sir, to have met you here.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: The beds i’ th’ East are soft; and thanks to you,
That called me timelier than my purpose hither,
For I have gained by ’t.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Since I saw you last,
There’s a change upon you.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Well, I know not
What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face,
But in my bosom shall she never come
To make my heart her vassal.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Well met here.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: I hope so, Lepidus. Thus we are agreed.
I crave our composition may be written
And sealed between us.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: That’s the next to do.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: We’ll feast each other ere we part, and let’s
Draw lots who shall begin.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: That will I, Pompey.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: No, Antony, take the lot. But, first or last,
Your fine Egyptian cookery shall have
The fame. I have heard that Julius Caesar
Grew fat with feasting there.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: You have heard much.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: I have fair meanings, sir.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: And fair words to them.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Then so much have I heard.
And I have heard Apollodorus carried—

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: No more of that. He did so.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: What, I pray you?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: A certain queen to Caesar in a mattress.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: I know thee now. How far’st thou, soldier?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Well,
And well am like to do, for I perceive
Four feasts are toward.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Let me shake thy hand.
I never hated thee. I have seen thee fight
When I have envied thy behavior.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Sir,
I never loved you much, but I ha’ praised you
When you have well deserved ten times as much
As I have said you did.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Enjoy thy plainness;
It nothing ill becomes thee.—
Aboard my galley I invite you all.
Will you lead, lords?

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Show ’s the way, sir.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Come.

div.stage: They exit, except for Enobarbus and Menas.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p:
Thy father, Pompey, would ne’er have
made this treaty.— You and I have known, sir.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: At sea, I think.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: We have, sir.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: You have done well by water.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: And you by land.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
I will praise any man that will praise me,
though it cannot be denied what I have done by
land.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: Nor what I have done by water.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Yes, something you can deny for your own
safety: you have been a great thief by sea.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: And you by land.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
There I deny my land service. But give me
your hand, Menas. They clasp hands. If our eyes
had authority, here they might take two thieves
kissing.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p:
All men’s faces are true, whatsome’er their
hands are.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
But there is never a fair woman has a true
face.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: No slander. They steal hearts.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: We came hither to fight with you.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p:
For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a
drinking. Pompey doth this day laugh away his
fortune.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
If he do, sure he cannot weep ’t back
again.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p:
You’ve said, sir. We looked not for Mark Antony
here. Pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: Caesar’s sister is called Octavia.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: True, sir. She was the wife of Caius Marcellus.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
But she is now the wife of Marcus
Antonius.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: Pray you, sir?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: ’Tis true.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: Then is Caesar and he forever knit together.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
If I were bound to divine of this unity, I
would not prophesy so.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p:
I think the policy of that purpose made more in
the marriage than the love of the parties.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
I think so, too. But you shall find the band
that seems to tie their friendship together will be
the very strangler of their amity. Octavia is of a holy,
cold, and still conversation.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: Who would not have his wife so?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Not he that himself is not so, which is
Mark Antony. He will to his Egyptian dish again.
Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in
Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is the
strength of their amity shall prove the immediate
author of their variance. Antony will use his affection
where it is. He married but his occasion here.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p:
And thus it may be. Come, sir, will you aboard?
I have a health for you.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
I shall take it, sir. We have used our throats
in Egypt.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.p: Come, let’s away.

div.head: Scene 7
div.stage: Music plays. Enter two or three Servants with a banquet.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT
sp.p:
Here they’ll be, man. Some o’ their
plants are ill-rooted already. The least wind i’ th’
world will blow them down.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT
sp.p: Lepidus is high-colored.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT
sp.p: They have made him drink alms-drink.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT
sp.p:
As they pinch one another by the
disposition, he cries out “ No more,” reconciles
them to his entreaty and himself to th’ drink.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT
sp.p:
But it raises the greater war between
him and his discretion.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT
sp.p:
Why, this it is to have a name in great
men’s fellowship. I had as lief have a reed that will
do me no service as a partisan I could not heave.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT
sp.p:
To be called into a huge sphere, and not
to be seen to move in ’t, are the holes where eyes
should be, which pitifully disaster the cheeks.

div.stage: A sennet sounded. Enter Caesar, Antony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Maecenas, Enobarbus, Menas, with other Captains and a Boy.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o’ th’ Nile
By certain scales i’ th’ Pyramid; they know
By th’ height, the lowness, or the mean if dearth
Or foison follow. The higher Nilus swells,
The more it promises. As it ebbs, the seedsman
Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain,
And shortly comes to harvest.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.p: You’ve strange serpents there?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: Ay, Lepidus.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.p:
Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your
mud by the operation of your sun; so is your
crocodile.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: They are so.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Sit, and some wine. A health to Lepidus!

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.p:
I am not so well as I should be, but I’ll ne’er
out.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p:
Not till you have slept. I fear me
you’ll be in till then.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.p:
Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies’
pyramises are very goodly things. Without contradiction
I have heard that.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Pompey, a word.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Say in mine ear what is ’t.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Forsake thy seat, I do beseech thee, captain,
And hear me speak a word.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Forbear me till anon.— This wine for Lepidus!

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.p: What manner o’ thing is your crocodile?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p:
It is shaped, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as
it hath breadth. It is just so high as it is, and moves
with it own organs. It lives by that which nourisheth
it, and the elements once out of it, it
transmigrates.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.p: What color is it of?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: Of it own color too.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.p: ’Tis a strange serpent.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p: ’Tis so, and the tears of it are wet.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.p:
Will this description satisfy
him?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.p:
With the health that Pompey gives him, else he
is a very epicure.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Go hang, sir, hang! Tell me of that? Away!
Do as I bid you.— Where’s this cup I called for?

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: If for the sake of merit thou wilt hear me,
Rise from thy stool.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: I think th’ art mad!
sp.stage: He rises, and they walk aside.
sp.l: The matter?

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Thou hast served me with much faith. What’s else to say?—
Be jolly, lords.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: These quicksands, Lepidus,
Keep off them, for you sink.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Wilt thou be lord of all the world?

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That’s twice.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: How should that be?

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: But entertain it,
And though thou think me poor, I am the man
Will give thee all the world.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Hast thou drunk well?

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: No, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup.
Thou art, if thou dar’st be, the earthly Jove.
Whate’er the ocean pales or sky inclips
Is thine, if thou wilt ha ’t.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Show me which way.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: These three world-sharers, these competitors,
Are in thy vessel. Let me cut the cable,
And when we are put off, fall to their throats.
All there is thine.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Ah, this thou shouldst have done
And not have spoke on ’t! In me ’tis villainy;
In thee ’t had been good service. Thou must know
’Tis not my profit that does lead mine honor;
Mine honor, it. Repent that e’er thy tongue
Hath so betrayed thine act. Being done unknown,
I should have found it afterwards well done,
But must condemn it now. Desist and drink.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: For this
I’ll never follow thy palled fortunes more.
Who seeks and will not take when once ’tis offered
Shall never find it more.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: This health to Lepidus!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Bear him ashore.— I’ll pledge it for him, Pompey.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Here’s to thee, Menas.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Enobarbus, welcome.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Fill till the cup be hid.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.stage: , pointing to the Servant carrying Lepidus
sp.l: There’s a strong fellow, Menas.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: He bears
The third part of the world, man. Seest not?

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: The third part, then, is drunk. Would it were all,
That it might go on wheels.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Drink thou. Increase the reels.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Come.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels, ho!
Here’s to Caesar.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I could well forbear ’t.
It’s monstrous labor when I wash my brain
And it grows fouler.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Be a child o’ th’ time.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Possess it, I’ll make answer.
But I had rather fast from all, four days,
Than drink so much in one.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Ha, my brave emperor,
Shall we dance now the Egyptian bacchanals
And celebrate our drink?

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: Let’s ha ’t, good soldier.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Come, let’s all take hands
Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense
In soft and delicate Lethe.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: All take hands.
Make battery to our ears with the loud music,
The while I’ll place you; then the boy shall sing.
The holding every man shall beat as loud
As his strong sides can volley.

div.stage: Music plays. Enobarbus places them hand in hand.
div.label: The Song.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: Come, thou monarch of the vine,
Plumpy Bacchus, with pink eyne.
In thy vats our cares be drowned.
With thy grapes our hairs be crowned.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Cup us till the world go round,
Cup us till the world go round.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: What would you more?— Pompey, goodnight.— Good brother,
Let me request you off. Our graver business
Frowns at this levity.— Gentle lords, let’s part.
You see we have burnt our cheeks. Strong Enobarb
Is weaker than the wine, and mine own tongue
Splits what it speaks. The wild disguise hath almost
Anticked us all. What needs more words? Goodnight.
Good Antony, your hand.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: I’ll try you on the shore.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: And shall, sir. Give ’s your hand.

sp.speaker: POMPEY
sp.l: O, Antony, you have my father’s house.
But what? We are friends! Come down into the boat.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Take heed you fall not.
sp.stage: All but Menas and Enobarbus exit.
sp.l: Menas, I’ll not on shore.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: No, to my cabin. These drums, these trumpets, flutes! What!
Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell
To these great fellows. Sound and be hanged. Sound out!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Hoo, says ’a! There’s my cap!

div.stage: He throws his cap in the air.

sp.speaker: MENAS
sp.l: Hoo! Noble captain, come.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Ventidius as it were in triumph, the dead body of Pacorus borne before him; with Silius and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: VENTIDIUS
sp.l: Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck, and now
Pleased Fortune does of Marcus Crassus’ death
Make me revenger. Bear the King’s son’s body
Before our army. Thy Pacorus, Orodes,
Pays this for Marcus Crassus.

sp.speaker: SILIUS
sp.l: Noble Ventidius,
Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy sword is warm,
The fugitive Parthians follow. Spur through Media,
Mesopotamia, and the shelters whither
The routed fly. So thy grand captain, Antony,
Shall set thee on triumphant chariots and
Put garlands on thy head.

sp.speaker: VENTIDIUS
sp.l: O, Silius, Silius,
I have done enough. A lower place, note well,
May make too great an act. For learn this, Silius:
Better to leave undone than by our deed
Acquire too high a fame when him we serve ’s away.
Caesar and Antony have ever won
More in their officer than person. Sossius,
One of my place in Syria, his lieutenant,
For quick accumulation of renown,
Which he achieved by th’ minute, lost his favor.
Who does i’ th’ wars more than his captain can
Becomes his captain’s captain; and ambition,
The soldier’s virtue, rather makes choice of loss
Than gain which darkens him.
I could do more to do Antonius good,
But ’twould offend him. And in his offense
Should my performance perish.

sp.speaker: SILIUS
sp.l: Thou hast, Ventidius, that
Without the which a soldier and his sword
Grants scarce distinction. Thou wilt write to Antony?

sp.speaker: VENTIDIUS
sp.l: I’ll humbly signify what in his name,
That magical word of war, we have effected;
How, with his banners and his well-paid ranks,
The ne’er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia
We have jaded out o’ th’ field.

sp.speaker: SILIUS
sp.l: Where is he now?

sp.speaker: VENTIDIUS
sp.l: He purposeth to Athens, whither, with what haste
The weight we must convey with ’s will permit,
We shall appear before him.— On there, pass along!

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Agrippa at one door, Enobarbus at another.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: What, are the brothers parted?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: They have dispatched with Pompey; he is gone.
The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps
To part from Rome. Caesar is sad, and Lepidus,
Since Pompey’s feast, as Menas says, is troubled
With the greensickness.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: ’Tis a noble Lepidus.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: A very fine one. O, how he loves Caesar!

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Caesar? Why, he’s the Jupiter of men.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: What’s Antony? The god of Jupiter.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Spake you of Caesar? How, the nonpareil!

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: O Antony, O thou Arabian bird!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Would you praise Caesar, say “ Caesar.” Go no further.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: But he loves Caesar best, yet he loves Antony.
Hoo, hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot
Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number— hoo!—
His love to Antony. But as for Caesar,
Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Both he loves.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: They are his shards and he their beetle.
So,
This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Good fortune, worthy soldier, and farewell.

div.stage: Enter Caesar, Antony, Lepidus, and Octavia.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: No further, sir.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: You take from me a great part of myself.
Use me well in ’t.— Sister, prove such a wife
As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest bond
Shall pass on thy approof.— Most noble Antony,
Let not the piece of virtue which is set
Betwixt us, as the cement of our love
To keep it builded, be the ram to batter
The fortress of it. For better might we
Have loved without this mean, if on both parts
This be not cherished.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Make me not offended
In your distrust.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I have said.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: You shall not find,
Though you be therein curious, the least cause
For what you seem to fear. So the gods keep you,
And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends.
We will here part.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well.
The elements be kind to thee and make
Thy spirits all of comfort. Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: My noble brother.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: The April’s in her eyes. It is love’s spring,
And these the showers to bring it on.— Be cheerful.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: Sir, look well to my husband’s house, and—

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: What, Octavia?

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: I’ll tell you in your ear.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can
Her heart inform her tongue— the swan’s-down feather
That stands upon the swell at the full of tide
And neither way inclines.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Will Caesar weep?

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: He has a cloud in ’s face.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: He were the worse for that were he a horse;
So is he being a man.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Why, Enobarbus,
When Antony found Julius Caesar dead,
He cried almost to roaring. And he wept
When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: That year indeed he was troubled with a rheum.
What willingly he did confound he wailed,
Believe ’t, till I wept too.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: No, sweet Octavia,
You shall hear from me still. The time shall not
Outgo my thinking on you.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Come, sir, come,
I’ll wrestle with you in my strength of love.
Look, here I have you, thus I let you go,
And give you to the gods.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Adieu, be happy.

sp.speaker: LEPIDUS
sp.l: Let all the number of the stars give light
To thy fair way.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Farewell, farewell.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Farewell.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Alexas.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Where is the fellow?

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: Half afeard to come.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Go to, go to.— Come hither, sir.

sp.speaker: ALEXAS
sp.l: Good Majesty,
Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you
But when you are well pleased.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: That Herod’s head
I’ll have! But how, when Antony is gone,
Through whom I might command it?— Come thou near.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Most gracious Majesty!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Did’st thou behold Octavia?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Ay, dread queen.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Madam, in Rome.
I looked her in the face and saw her led
Between her brother and Mark Antony.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Is she as tall as me?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: She is not, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Didst hear her speak? Is she shrill-tongued or low?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Madam, I heard her speak. She is low-voiced.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: That’s not so good. He cannot like her long.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Like her? O Isis, ’tis impossible!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I think so, Charmian: dull of tongue, and dwarfish!—
What majesty is in her gait? Remember,
If e’er thou looked’st on majesty.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: She creeps.
Her motion and her station are as one.
She shows a body rather than a life,
A statue than a breather.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Is this certain?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Or I have no observance.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Three in Egypt
Cannot make better note.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: He’s very knowing.
I do perceive ’t. There’s nothing in her yet.
The fellow has good judgment.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Guess at her years, I prithee.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Madam, she was a widow.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Widow? Charmian, hark.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: And I do think she’s thirty.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Bear’st thou her face in mind? Is ’t long or round?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Round even to faultiness.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so.
Her hair what color?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Brown, madam, and her forehead
As low as she would wish it.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: There’s gold for thee.
Thou must not take my former sharpness ill.
I will employ thee back again. I find thee
Most fit for business. Go, make thee ready.
Our letters are prepared.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: A proper man.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Indeed he is so. I repent me much
That so I harried him. Why, methinks, by him,
This creature’s no such thing.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Nothing, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: The man hath seen some majesty, and should know.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Hath he seen majesty? Isis else defend,
And serving you so long!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I have one thing more to ask him yet, good Charmian,
But ’tis no matter. Thou shalt bring him to me
Where I will write. All may be well enough.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: I warrant you, madam.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Nay, nay, Octavia, not only that—
That were excusable, that and thousands more
