Of semblable import— but he hath waged
New wars ’gainst Pompey; made his will and read it
To public ear;
Spoke scantly of me; when perforce he could not
But pay me terms of honor, cold and sickly
He vented them, most narrow measure lent me;
When the best hint was given him, he not took ’t,
Or did it from his teeth.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: O, my good lord,
Believe not all, or if you must believe,
Stomach not all. A more unhappy lady,
If this division chance, ne’er stood between,
Praying for both parts.
The good gods will mock me presently
When I shall pray “ O, bless my lord and husband!”
Undo that prayer by crying out as loud
“ O, bless my brother!” Husband win, win brother
Prays and destroys the prayer; no midway
’Twixt these extremes at all.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Gentle Octavia,
Let your best love draw to that point which seeks
Best to preserve it. If I lose mine honor,
I lose myself; better I were not yours
Than yours so branchless. But, as you requested,
Yourself shall go between ’s. The meantime, lady,
I’ll raise the preparation of a war
Shall stain your brother. Make your soonest haste,
So your desires are yours.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: Thanks to my lord.
The Jove of power make me, most weak, most weak,
Your reconciler. Wars ’twixt you twain would be
As if the world should cleave, and that slain men
Should solder up the rift.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: When it appears to you where this begins,
Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults
Can never be so equal that your love
Can equally move with them. Provide your going;
Choose your own company, and command what cost
Your heart has mind to.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: How now, friend Eros?

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.p: There’s strange news come, sir.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: What, man?

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.p:
Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon
Pompey.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.p: This is old. What is the success?

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.p:
Caesar, having made use of him in the wars
’gainst Pompey, presently denied him rivality,
would not let him partake in the glory of the action;
and, not resting here, accuses him of letters he had
formerly wrote to Pompey; upon his own appeal
seizes him. So the poor third is up, till death enlarge
his confine.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps, no more,
And throw between them all the food thou hast,
They’ll grind the one the other. Where’s Antony?

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: He’s walking in the garden, thus, and spurns
The rush that lies before him; cries “ Fool Lepidus!”
And threats the throat of that his officer
That murdered Pompey.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Our great navy’s rigged.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: For Italy and Caesar. More, Domitius:
My lord desires you presently. My news
I might have told hereafter.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: ’Twill be naught,
But let it be. Bring me to Antony.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Come, sir.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Contemning Rome, he has done all this and more
In Alexandria. Here’s the manner of ’t:
I’ th’ marketplace, on a tribunal silvered,
Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold
Were publicly enthroned. At the feet sat
Caesarion, whom they call my father’s son,
And all the unlawful issue that their lust
Since then hath made between them. Unto her
He gave the stablishment of Egypt, made her
Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia,
Absolute queen.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: This in the public eye?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I’ th’ common showplace where they exercise.
His sons he there proclaimed the kings of kings.
Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia
He gave to Alexander; to Ptolemy he assigned
Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia. She
In th’ habiliments of the goddess Isis
That day appeared, and oft before gave audience,
As ’tis reported, so.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: Let Rome be thus informed.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Who, queasy with his insolence already,
Will their good thoughts call from him.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: The people knows it and have now received
His accusations.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Who does he accuse?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Caesar, and that, having in Sicily
Sextus Pompeius spoiled, we had not rated him
His part o’ th’ isle. Then does he say he lent me
Some shipping, unrestored. Lastly, he frets
That Lepidus of the triumvirate
Should be deposed and, being, that we detain
All his revenue.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Sir, this should be answered.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: ’Tis done already, and the messenger gone.
I have told him Lepidus was grown too cruel,
That he his high authority abused
And did deserve his change. For what I have conquered,
I grant him part; but then in his Armenia
And other of his conquered kingdoms I
Demand the like.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: He’ll never yield to that.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Nor must not then be yielded to in this.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: Hail, Caesar, and my lord! Hail, most dear Caesar.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: That ever I should call thee castaway!

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: You have not called me so, nor have you cause.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Why have you stol’n upon us thus? You come not
Like Caesar’s sister. The wife of Antony
Should have an army for an usher and
The neighs of horse to tell of her approach
Long ere she did appear. The trees by th’ way
Should have borne men, and expectation fainted,
Longing for what it had not. Nay, the dust
Should have ascended to the roof of heaven,
Raised by your populous troops. But you are come
A market-maid to Rome, and have prevented
The ostentation of our love, which, left unshown,
Is often left unloved. We should have met you
By sea and land, supplying every stage
With an augmented greeting.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: Good my lord,
To come thus was I not constrained, but did it
On my free will. My lord, Mark Antony,
Hearing that you prepared for war, acquainted
My grievèd ear withal, whereon I begged
His pardon for return.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Which soon he granted,
Being an abstract ’tween his lust and him.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: Do not say so, my lord.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: I have eyes upon him,
And his affairs come to me on the wind.
Where is he now?

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: My lord, in Athens.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: No, my most wrongèd sister. Cleopatra
Hath nodded him to her. He hath given his empire
Up to a whore, who now are levying
The kings o’ th’ Earth for war. He hath assembled
Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus
Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King
Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas;
King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont;
Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, King
Of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas,
The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia,
With a more larger list of scepters.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: Ay me, most wretched,
That have my heart parted betwixt two friends
That does afflict each other!

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Welcome hither.
Your letters did withhold our breaking forth
Till we perceived both how you were wrong led
And we in negligent danger. Cheer your heart.
Be you not troubled with the time, which drives
O’er your content these strong necessities,
But let determined things to destiny
Hold unbewailed their way. Welcome to Rome,
Nothing more dear to me. You are abused
Beyond the mark of thought, and the high gods,
To do you justice, makes his ministers
Of us and those that love you. Best of comfort,
And ever welcome to us.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Welcome, lady.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: Welcome, dear madam.
Each heart in Rome does love and pity you;
Only th’ adulterous Antony, most large
In his abominations, turns you off
And gives his potent regiment to a trull
That noises it against us.

sp.speaker: OCTAVIA
sp.l: Is it so, sir?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Most certain. Sister, welcome. Pray you
Be ever known to patience. My dear’st sister!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I will be even with thee, doubt it not.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: But why, why, why?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars
And say’st it is not fit.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Well, is it, is it?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Is ’t not denounced against us? Why should not we
Be there in person?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Well, I could reply:
If we should serve with horse and mares together,
The horse were merely lost. The mares would bear
A soldier and his horse.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What is ’t you say?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Your presence needs must puzzle Antony,
Take from his heart, take from his brain, from ’s time
What should not then be spared. He is already
Traduced for levity, and ’tis said in Rome
That Photinus, an eunuch, and your maids
Manage this war.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Sink Rome, and their tongues rot
That speak against us! A charge we bear i’ th’ war,
And as the president of my kingdom will
Appear there for a man. Speak not against it.
I will not stay behind.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Nay, I have done.
Here comes the Emperor.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Is it not strange, Canidius,
That from Tarentum and Brundusium
He could so quickly cut the Ionian Sea
And take in Toryne?— You have heard on ’t, sweet?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Celerity is never more admired
Than by the negligent.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: A good rebuke,
Which might have well becomed the best of men,
To taunt at slackness.— Canidius, we will fight
With him by sea.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: By sea, what else?

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: Why will
My lord do so?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: For that he dares us to ’t.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: So hath my lord dared him to single fight.

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia,
Where Caesar fought with Pompey. But these offers,
Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off,
And so should you.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Your ships are not well manned,
Your mariners are muleteers, reapers, people
Engrossed by swift impress. In Caesar’s fleet
Are those that often have ’gainst Pompey fought.
Their ships are yare, yours heavy. No disgrace
Shall fall you for refusing him at sea,
Being prepared for land.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: By sea, by sea.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Most worthy sir, you therein throw away
The absolute soldiership you have by land,
Distract your army, which doth most consist
Of war-marked footmen, leave unexecuted
Your own renownèd knowledge, quite forgo
The way which promises assurance, and
Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard
From firm security.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I’ll fight at sea.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I have sixty sails, Caesar none better.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Our overplus of shipping will we burn,
And with the rest full-manned, from th’ head of Actium
Beat th’ approaching Caesar. But if we fail,
We then can do ’t at land.
Thy business?

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: The news is true, my lord; he is descried.
Caesar has taken Toryne.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Can he be there in person? ’Tis impossible;
Strange that his power should be. Canidius,
Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land,
And our twelve thousand horse. We’ll to our ship.—
Away, my Thetis.
How now, worthy soldier?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: O noble emperor, do not fight by sea!
Trust not to rotten planks. Do you misdoubt
This sword and these my wounds? Let th’ Egyptians
And the Phoenicians go a-ducking. We
Have used to conquer standing on the earth
And fighting foot to foot.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Well, well, away.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: By Hercules, I think I am i’ th’ right.

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: Soldier, thou art, but his whole action grows
Not in the power on ’t. So our leader’s led,
And we are women’s men.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: You keep by land
The legions and the horse whole, do you not?

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius,
Publicola, and Caelius are for sea,
But we keep whole by land. This speed of Caesar’s
Carries beyond belief.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: While he was yet in Rome,
His power went out in such distractions as
Beguiled all spies.

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: Who’s his lieutenant, hear you?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: They say one Taurus.

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: Well I know the man.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: The Emperor calls Canidius.

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: With news the time’s in labor, and throws forth
Each minute some.

div.head: Scene 8
div.stage: Enter Caesar with his army, and Taurus, marching.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Taurus!

sp.speaker: TAURUS
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Strike not by land, keep whole. Provoke not battle
Till we have done at sea. Do not exceed
The prescript of this scroll.
Our fortune lies
Upon this jump.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Set we our squadrons on yond side o’ th’ hill
In eye of Caesar’s battle, from which place
We may the number of the ships behold
And so proceed accordingly.

div.head: Scene 10
div.stage: Canidius marcheth with his land army one way over the stage, and Taurus the lieutenant of Caesar the other way. After their going in is heard the noise of a sea fight.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Naught, naught, all naught! I can behold no longer.
Th’ Antoniad, the Egyptian admiral,
With all their sixty, fly and turn the rudder.
To see ’t mine eyes are blasted.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: Gods and goddesses,
All the whole synod of them!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: What’s thy passion?

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: The greater cantle of the world is lost
With very ignorance. We have kissed away
Kingdoms and provinces.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: How appears the fight?

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: On our side, like the tokened pestilence,
Where death is sure. Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt,
Whom leprosy o’ertake, i’ th’ midst o’ th’ fight,
When vantage like a pair of twins appeared
Both as the same— or, rather, ours the elder—
The breeze upon her like a cow in June,
Hoists sails and flies.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: That I beheld.
Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not
Endure a further view.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: She once being loofed,
The noble ruin of her magic, Antony,
Claps on his sea-wing and, like a doting mallard,
Leaving the fight in height, flies after her.
I never saw an action of such shame.
Experience, manhood, honor ne’er before
Did violate so itself.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Alack, alack.

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: Our fortune on the sea is out of breath
And sinks most lamentably. Had our general
Been what he knew himself, it had gone well.
O, he has given example for our flight
Most grossly by his own.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Ay, are you thereabouts? Why then goodnight indeed.

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: ’Tis easy to ’t, and there I will attend
What further comes.

sp.speaker: CANIDIUS
sp.l: To Caesar will I render
My legions and my horse. Six kings already
Show me the way of yielding.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: I’ll yet follow
The wounded chance of Antony, though my reason
Sits in the wind against me.

div.head: Scene 11

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Hark, the land bids me tread no more upon ’t.
It is ashamed to bear me. Friends, come hither.
I am so lated in the world that I
Have lost my way forever. I have a ship
Laden with gold. Take that, divide it. Fly,
And make your peace with Caesar.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Fly? Not we!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I have fled myself and have instructed cowards
To run and show their shoulders. Friends, begone.
I have myself resolved upon a course
Which has no need of you. Begone.
My treasure’s in the harbor; take it. O,
I followed that I blush to look upon!
My very hairs do mutiny, for the white
Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them
For fear and doting. Friends, begone. You shall
Have letters from me to some friends that will
Sweep your way for you. Pray you look not sad,
Nor make replies of loathness. Take the hint
Which my despair proclaims. Let that be left
Which leaves itself. To the seaside straightway!
I will possess you of that ship and treasure.
Leave me, I pray, a little— pray you, now,
Nay, do so— for indeed I have lost command.
Therefore I pray you— I’ll see you by and by.

div.stage: Attendants move aside. Antony sits down.
Enter Cleopatra led by Charmian, Iras, and Eros.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Nay, gentle madam, to him, comfort him.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: Do, most dear queen.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Do! Why, what else?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Let me sit down. O Juno!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: No, no, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: See you here, sir?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Oh fie, fie, fie!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: Madam, O good empress!

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Sir, sir—

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Yes, my lord, yes. He at Philippi kept
His sword e’en like a dancer, while I struck
The lean and wrinkled Cassius, and ’twas I
That the mad Brutus ended. He alone
Dealt on lieutenantry, and no practice had
In the brave squares of war, yet now— no matter.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Ah, stand by.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: The Queen, my lord, the Queen.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: Go to him, madam; speak to him.
He’s unqualitied with very shame.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Well, then, sustain me. O!

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Most noble sir, arise. The Queen approaches.
Her head’s declined, and death will seize her but
Your comfort makes the rescue.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I have offended reputation,
A most unnoble swerving.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Sir, the Queen.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: O, whither hast them led me, Egypt? See
How I convey my shame out of thine eyes,
By looking back what I have left behind
’Stroyed in dishonor.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, my lord, my lord,
Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought
You would have followed.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Egypt, thou knew’st too well
My heart was to thy rudder tied by th’ strings,
And thou shouldst tow me after. O’er my spirit
Thy full supremacy thou knew’st, and that
Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods
Command me.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, my pardon!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Now I must
To the young man send humble treaties, dodge
And palter in the shifts of lowness, who
With half the bulk o’ th’ world played as I pleased,
Making and marring fortunes. You did know
How much you were my conqueror, and that
My sword, made weak by my affection, would
Obey it on all cause.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Pardon, pardon!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Fall not a tear, I say; one of them rates
All that is won and lost. Give me a kiss.
Even this repays me.—
We sent our schoolmaster. Is he come back?—
Love, I am full of lead.— Some wine
Within there, and our viands! Fortune knows
We scorn her most when most she offers blows.

div.head: Scene 12
div.stage: Enter Caesar, Agrippa, Thidias, and Dolabella, with others.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Let him appear that’s come from Antony.
Know you him?

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Caesar, ’tis his schoolmaster—
An argument that he is plucked, when hither
He sends so poor a pinion of his wing,
Which had superfluous kings for messengers
Not many moons gone by.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Approach, and speak.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR
sp.l: Such as I am, I come from Antony.
I was of late as petty to his ends
As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf
To his grand sea.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Be ’t so. Declare thine office.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR
sp.l: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and
Requires to live in Egypt, which not granted,
He lessens his requests, and to thee sues
To let him breathe between the heavens and Earth,
A private man in Athens. This for him.
Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness,
Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves
The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs,
Now hazarded to thy grace.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: For Antony,
I have no ears to his request. The Queen
Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she
From Egypt drive her all-disgracèd friend,
Or take his life there. This if she perform,
She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR
sp.l: Fortune pursue thee!

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Bring him through the bands.
To Thidias. To try thy eloquence now ’tis time. Dispatch.
From Antony win Cleopatra. Promise,
And in our name, what she requires; add more,
From thine invention, offers. Women are not
In their best fortunes strong, but want will perjure
The ne’er-touched vestal. Try thy cunning, Thidias.
Make thine own edict for thy pains, which we
Will answer as a law.

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: Caesar, I go.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw,
And what thou think’st his very action speaks
In every power that moves.

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: Caesar, I shall.

div.head: Scene 13
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian, and Iras.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What shall we do, Enobarbus?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Think, and die.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Is Antony or we in fault for this?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Antony only, that would make his will
Lord of his reason. What though you fled
From that great face of war, whose several ranges
Frighted each other? Why should he follow?
The itch of his affection should not then
Have nicked his captainship, at such a point,
When half to half the world opposed, he being
The merèd question. ’Twas a shame no less
Than was his loss, to course your flying flags
And leave his navy gazing.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Prithee, peace.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Is that his answer?

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR
sp.l: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: The Queen shall then have courtesy, so she
Will yield us up?

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR
sp.l: He says so.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Let her know ’t.—
To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head,
And he will fill thy wishes to the brim
With principalities.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: That head, my lord?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: To him again. Tell him he wears the rose
Of youth upon him, from which the world should note
Something particular: his coin, ships, legions
May be a coward’s, whose ministers would prevail
Under the service of a child as soon
As i’ th’ command of Caesar. I dare him therefore
To lay his gay caparisons apart
And answer me declined, sword against sword,
Ourselves alone. I’ll write it. Follow me.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Yes, like enough, high-battled Caesar will
Unstate his happiness and be staged to th’ show
Against a sworder! I see men’s judgments are
A parcel of their fortunes, and things outward
Do draw the inward quality after them
To suffer all alike. That he should dream,
Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will
Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdued
His judgment too.

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: A messenger from Caesar.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What, no more ceremony? See, my women,
Against the blown rose may they stop their nose
That kneeled unto the buds.— Admit him, sir.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Mine honesty and I begin to square.
The loyalty well held to fools does make
Our faith mere folly. Yet he that can endure
To follow with allegiance a fall’n lord
Does conquer him that did his master conquer,
And earns a place i’ th’ story.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Caesar’s will?

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: Hear it apart.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: None but friends. Say boldly.

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: So haply are they friends to Antony.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has,
Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master
Will leap to be his friend. For us, you know
Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar’s.

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: So.—
Thus then, thou most renowned: Caesar entreats
Not to consider in what case thou stand’st
Further than he is Caesar.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Go on; right royal.

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: He knows that you embrace not Antony
As you did love, but as you feared him.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O!

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: The scars upon your honor therefore he
Does pity as constrainèd blemishes,
Not as deserved.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: He is a god and knows
What is most right. Mine honor was not yielded,
But conquered merely.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: To be sure of that,
I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky
That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for
Thy dearest quit thee.

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: Shall I say to Caesar
What you require of him? For he partly begs
To be desired to give. It much would please him
That of his fortunes you should make a staff
To lean upon. But it would warm his spirits
To hear from me you had left Antony
And put yourself under his shroud,
The universal landlord.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What’s your name?

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: My name is Thidias.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Most kind messenger,
Say to great Caesar this in deputation:
I kiss his conqu’ring hand. Tell him I am prompt
To lay my crown at ’s feet, and there to kneel.
Tell him, from his all-obeying breath I hear
The doom of Egypt.

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: ’Tis your noblest course.
Wisdom and fortune combating together,
If that the former dare but what it can,
No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay
My duty on your hand.

div.stage: She gives him her hand to kiss.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Your Caesar’s father oft,
When he hath mused of taking kingdoms in,
Bestowed his lips on that unworthy place
As it rained kisses.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Favors? By Jove that thunders!
What art thou, fellow?

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: One that but performs
The bidding of the fullest man and worthiest
To have command obeyed.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: You will be whipped.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Approach there!— Ah, you kite!— Now, gods and devils,
Authority melts from me. Of late when I cried “ Ho!”
Like boys unto a muss kings would start forth
And cry “ Your will?” Have you no ears? I am
Antony yet.
Take hence this jack and whip him.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: ’Tis better playing with a lion’s whelp
Than with an old one dying.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Moon and stars!
Whip him! Were ’t twenty of the greatest tributaries
That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them
So saucy with the hand of she here— what’s her name
Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him, fellows,
Till like a boy you see him cringe his face
And whine aloud for mercy. Take him hence.

sp.speaker: THIDIAS
sp.l: Mark Antony—

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Tug him away. Being whipped,
Bring him again. This jack of Caesar’s shall
Bear us an errand to him.
To Cleopatra. You were half blasted ere I knew you. Ha!
Have I my pillow left unpressed in Rome,
Forborne the getting of a lawful race,
And by a gem of women, to be abused
By one that looks on feeders?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Good my lord—

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: You have been a boggler ever.
But when we in our viciousness grow hard—
O, misery on ’t!— the wise gods seel our eyes,
In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us
Adore our errors, laugh at ’s while we strut
To our confusion.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O, is ’t come to this?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I found you as a morsel cold upon
Dead Caesar’s trencher; nay, you were a fragment
Of Gneius Pompey’s, besides what hotter hours,
Unregistered in vulgar fame, you have
Luxuriously picked out. For I am sure,
Though you can guess what temperance should be,
You know not what it is.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Wherefore is this?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: To let a fellow that will take rewards
And say “ God quit you!” be familiar with
My playfellow, your hand, this kingly seal
And plighter of high hearts! O, that I were
Upon the hill of Basan, to outroar
The hornèd herd! For I have savage cause,
And to proclaim it civilly were like
A haltered neck which does the hangman thank
For being yare about him.
Is he whipped?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: Soundly, my lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Cried he? And begged he pardon?

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.l: He did ask favor.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: If that thy father live, let him repent
Thou wast not made his daughter; and be thou sorry
To follow Caesar in his triumph, since
Thou hast been whipped for following him. Henceforth
The white hand of a lady fever thee;
Shake thou to look on ’t. Get thee back to Caesar.
Tell him thy entertainment. Look thou say
He makes me angry with him; for he seems
Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am,
Not what he knew I was. He makes me angry,
And at this time most easy ’tis to do ’t,
When my good stars that were my former guides
Have empty left their orbs and shot their fires
Into th’ abysm of hell. If he mislike
My speech and what is done, tell him he has
Hipparchus, my enfranchèd bondman, whom
He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture,
As he shall like to quit me. Urge it thou.
Hence with thy stripes, begone!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Have you done yet?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Alack, our terrene moon is now eclipsed,
And it portends alone the fall of Antony.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I must stay his time.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes
With one that ties his points?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Not know me yet?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Coldhearted toward me?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Ah, dear, if I be so,
From my cold heart let heaven engender hail
And poison it in the source, and the first stone
Drop in my neck; as it determines, so
Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite,
Till by degrees the memory of my womb,
Together with my brave Egyptians all,
By the discandying of this pelleted storm
Lie graveless till the flies and gnats of Nile
Have buried them for prey!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I am satisfied.
Caesar sits down in Alexandria, where
I will oppose his fate. Our force by land
Hath nobly held; our severed navy too
Have knit again, and fleet, threatening most sealike.
Where hast thou been, my heart? Dost thou hear, lady?
If from the field I shall return once more
To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood.
I and my sword will earn our chronicle.
There’s hope in ’t yet.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: That’s my brave lord!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I will be treble-sinewed, -hearted, -breathed,
And fight maliciously; for when mine hours
Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives
Of me for jests. But now I’ll set my teeth
And send to darkness all that stop me. Come,
Let’s have one other gaudy night. Call to me
All my sad captains. Fill our bowls once more.
Let’s mock the midnight bell.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: It is my birthday.
I had thought t’ have held it poor. But since my lord
Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: We will yet do well.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Call all his noble captains to my lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Do so; we’ll speak to them, and tonight I’ll force
The wine peep through their scars.— Come on, my queen,
There’s sap in ’t yet. The next time I do fight
I’ll make Death love me, for I will contend
Even with his pestilent scythe.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Now he’ll outstare the lightning. To be furious
Is to be frighted out of fear, and in that mood
The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still
A diminution in our captain’s brain
Restores his heart. When valor preys on reason,
It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek
Some way to leave him.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Caesar, Agrippa, and Maecenas, with his army, Caesar reading a letter.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: He calls me “ boy,” and chides as he had power
To beat me out of Egypt. My messenger
He hath whipped with rods, dares me to personal combat,
Caesar to Antony. Let the old ruffian know
I have many other ways to die; meantime
Laugh at his challenge.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: Caesar must think,
When one so great begins to rage, he’s hunted
Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now
Make boot of his distraction. Never anger
Made good guard for itself.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Let our best heads
Know that tomorrow the last of many battles
We mean to fight. Within our files there are,
Of those that served Mark Antony but late,
Enough to fetch him in. See it done,
And feast the army; we have store to do ’t,
And they have earned the waste. Poor Antony.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Antony, Cleopatra, Enobarbus, Charmian, Iras, with others.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: He will not fight with me, Domitius?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Why should he not?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune,
He is twenty men to one.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Tomorrow, soldier,
By sea and land I’ll fight. Or I will live
Or bathe my dying honor in the blood
Shall make it live again. Woo’t thou fight well?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: I’ll strike and cry “ Take all.”

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Well said. Come on.
Call forth my household servants.
Let’s tonight
Be bounteous at our meal.— Give me thy hand;
Thou hast been rightly honest.— So hast thou,—
Thou,— and thou,— and thou. You have served me well,
And kings have been your fellows.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What means this?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: ’Tis one of those odd tricks which sorrow shoots
Out of the mind.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: And thou art honest too.
I wish I could be made so many men,
And all of you clapped up together in
An Antony, that I might do you service
So good as you have done.

sp.speaker: ALL THE SERVITORS
sp.l: The gods forbid!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight.
Scant not my cups, and make as much of me
As when mine empire was your fellow too
And suffered my command.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: To make his followers weep.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Tend me tonight;
May be it is the period of your duty.
Haply you shall not see me more, or if,
A mangled shadow. Perchance tomorrow
You’ll serve another master. I look on you
As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends,
I turn you not away, but, like a master
Married to your good service, stay till death.
Tend me tonight two hours— I ask no more—
And the gods yield you for ’t!

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: What mean you, sir,
To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep,
And I, an ass, am onion-eyed. For shame,
Transform us not to women.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Ho, ho, ho!
Now the witch take me if I meant it thus!
Grace grow where those drops fall! My hearty friends,
You take me in too dolorous a sense,
For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you
To burn this night with torches. Know, my hearts,
I hope well of tomorrow, and will lead you
Where rather I’ll expect victorious life
Than death and honor. Let’s to supper, come,
And drown consideration.

div.head: Scene 3

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: Brother, goodnight. Tomorrow is the day.

sp.speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
sp.l: It will determine one way. Fare you well.
Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: Nothing. What news?

sp.speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
sp.l: Belike ’tis but a rumor. Goodnight to you.

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: Well, sir, goodnight.

div.stage: They meet other Soldiers who are entering.

sp.speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
sp.l: Soldiers, have careful watch.

sp.speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
sp.l: And you. Goodnight, goodnight.

div.stage: They place themselves in every corner of the stage.

sp.speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
sp.l: Here we; and if tomorrow
Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope
Our landmen will stand up.

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: ’Tis a brave army, and full of purpose.

stage.stage: Music of the hautboys is under the stage.

sp.speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
sp.l: Peace. What noise?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: List, list!

sp.speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
sp.l: Hark!

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: Music i’ th’ air.

sp.speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
sp.l: Under the earth.

sp.speaker: FOURTH SOLDIER
sp.l: It signs well, does it not?

sp.speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: Peace, I say. What should this mean?

sp.speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
sp.l: ’Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony loved,
Now leaves him.

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: Walk. Let’s see if other watchmen
Do hear what we do.

sp.speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
sp.l: How now, masters?

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: How now? How now? Do you hear this?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: Ay. Is ’t not strange?

sp.speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
sp.l: Do you hear, masters? Do you hear?

sp.speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
sp.l: Follow the noise so far as we have quarter.
Let’s see how it will give off.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Content. ’Tis strange.

div.head: Scene 4
div.stage: Enter Antony and Cleopatra, with Charmian, and others.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Eros! Mine armor, Eros!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Sleep a little.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: No, my chuck.— Eros, come, mine armor, Eros.
Come, good fellow, put thine iron on.
If fortune be not ours today, it is
Because we brave her. Come.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Nay, I’ll help too.
What’s this for?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Ah, let be, let be! Thou art
The armorer of my heart. False, false. This, this!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Sooth, la, I’ll help. Thus it must be.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Well, well,
We shall thrive now.— Seest thou, my good fellow?
Go, put on thy defenses.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Briefly, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Is not this buckled well?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Rarely, rarely.
He that unbuckles this, till we do please
To daff ’t for our repose, shall hear a storm.—
Thou fumblest, Eros, and my queen’s a squire
More tight at this than thou. Dispatch.— O love,
That thou couldst see my wars today, and knew’st
The royal occupation, thou shouldst see
A workman in ’t.
Good morrow to thee. Welcome.
Thou look’st like him that knows a warlike charge.
To business that we love we rise betime
And go to ’t with delight.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: A thousand, sir,
Early though ’t be, have on their riveted trim
And at the port expect you.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.l: The morn is fair. Good morrow, general.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Good morrow, general.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: ’Tis well blown, lads.
This morning, like the spirit of a youth
That means to be of note, begins betimes.
So, so.— Come, give me that. This way.— Well said.—
Fare thee well, dame.
Whate’er becomes of me,
This is a soldier’s kiss. Rebukable
And worthy shameful check it were to stand
On more mechanic compliment. I’ll leave thee
Now like a man of steel.— You that will fight,
Follow me close. I’ll bring you to ’t.— Adieu.

div.stage: Antony, Eros, Captains, and Soldiers exit.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Please you retire to your chamber?

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Lead me.
He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might
Determine this great war in single fight,
Then Antony— but now—. Well, on.

div.head: Scene 5
div.stage: Trumpets sound. Enter Antony and Eros, and a Soldier who meets them.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: The gods make this a happy day to Antony.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevailed
To make me fight at land.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: Had’st thou done so,
The kings that have revolted and the soldier
That has this morning left thee would have still
Followed thy heels.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Who’s gone this morning?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: Who?
One ever near thee. Call for Enobarbus,
He shall not hear thee, or from Caesar’s camp
Say “ I am none of thine.”

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: What sayest thou?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: Sir,
He is with Caesar.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Sir, his chests and treasure
He has not with him.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: Most certain.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Go, Eros, send his treasure after. Do it.
Detain no jot, I charge thee. Write to him—
I will subscribe— gentle adieus and greetings.
Say that I wish he never find more cause
To change a master. O, my fortunes have
Corrupted honest men. Dispatch.— Enobarbus!

div.head: Scene 6
div.stage: Flourish. Enter Agrippa, Caesar, with Enobarbus and Dolabella.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight.
Our will is Antony be took alive;
Make it so known.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Caesar, I shall.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: The time of universal peace is near.
Prove this a prosp’rous day, the three-nooked world
Shall bear the olive freely.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER
sp.l: Antony
Is come into the field.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Go charge Agrippa
Plant those that have revolted in the vant
That Antony may seem to spend his fury
Upon himself.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Alexas did revolt and went to Jewry on
Affairs of Antony, there did dissuade
Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar
And leave his master Antony. For this pains,
Caesar hath hanged him. Canidius and the rest
That fell away have entertainment but
No honorable trust. I have done ill,
Of which I do accuse myself so sorely
That I will joy no more.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: Enobarbus, Antony
Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with
His bounty overplus. The messenger
Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now
Unloading of his mules.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: I give it you.

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.l: Mock not, Enobarbus.
I tell you true. Best you safed the bringer
Out of the host. I must attend mine office
Or would have done ’t myself. Your emperor
Continues still a Jove.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: I am alone the villain of the Earth,
And feel I am so most. O Antony,
Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid
My better service, when my turpitude
Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart.
If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean
Shall outstrike thought, but thought will do ’t, I feel.
I fight against thee? No. I will go seek
Some ditch wherein to die; the foul’st best fits
My latter part of life.

div.head: Scene 7
div.stage: Alarum, Drums and Trumpets. Enter Agrippa, with other of Caesar’s soldiers.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: Retire! We have engaged ourselves too far.
Caesar himself has work, and our oppression
Exceeds what we expected.

div.stage: Alarums. Enter Antony, and Scarus wounded.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: O my brave emperor, this is fought indeed!
Had we done so at first, we had droven them home
With clouts about their heads.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Thou bleed’st apace.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: I had a wound here that was like a T,
But now ’tis made an H.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: They do retire.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: We’ll beat ’em into bench-holes. I have yet
Room for six scotches more.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves
For a fair victory.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: Let us score their backs
And snatch ’em up as we take hares, behind.
’Tis sport to maul a runner.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I will reward thee
Once for thy sprightly comfort and tenfold
For thy good valor. Come thee on.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: I’ll halt after.

div.head: Scene 8
div.stage: Alarum. Enter Antony again in a march; Scarus, with others.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: We have beat him to his camp. Run one before
And let the Queen know of our gests.
Tomorrow
Before the sun shall see ’s, we’ll spill the blood
That has today escaped. I thank you all,
For doughty-handed are you, and have fought
Not as you served the cause, but as ’t had been
Each man’s like mine. You have shown all Hectors.
Enter the city. Clip your wives, your friends.
Tell them your feats, whilst they with joyful tears
Wash the congealment from your wounds and kiss
The honored gashes whole.
Give me thy hand.
To this great fairy I’ll commend thy acts,
Make her thanks bless thee.— O, thou day o’ th’ world,
Chain mine armed neck. Leap thou, attire and all,
Through proof of harness to my heart, and there
Ride on the pants triumphing.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Lord of lords!
O infinite virtue, com’st thou smiling from
The world’s great snare uncaught?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Mine nightingale,
We have beat them to their beds. What, girl, though gray
Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha’ we
A brain that nourishes our nerves and can
Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man.
Commend unto his lips thy favoring hand.—
Kiss it, my warrior.
He hath fought today
As if a god in hate of mankind had
Destroyed in such a shape.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I’ll give thee, friend,
An armor all of gold. It was a king’s.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: He has deserved it, were it carbuncled
Like holy Phoebus’ car. Give me thy hand.
Through Alexandria make a jolly march.
Bear our hacked targets like the men that owe them.
Had our great palace the capacity
To camp this host, we all would sup together
And drink carouses to the next day’s fate,
Which promises royal peril.— Trumpeters,
With brazen din blast you the city’s ear.
Make mingle with our rattling taborins,
That heaven and Earth may strike their sounds together,
Applauding our approach.

div.head: Scene 9
div.stage: Enter a Sentry and his company. Enobarbus follows.

sp.speaker: SENTRY
sp.l: If we be not relieved within this hour,
We must return to th’ court of guard. The night
Is shiny, and they say we shall embattle
By th’ second hour i’ th’ morn.

sp.speaker: FIRST WATCH
sp.l: This last day was a shrewd one to ’s.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: O, bear me witness, night—

sp.speaker: SECOND WATCH
sp.l: What man is this?

sp.speaker: FIRST WATCH
sp.l: Stand close, and list him.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: Be witness to me, O thou blessèd moon,
When men revolted shall upon record
Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did
Before thy face repent.

sp.speaker: SENTRY
sp.l: Enobarbus?

sp.speaker: SECOND WATCH
sp.l: Peace! Hark further.

sp.speaker: ENOBARBUS
sp.l: O sovereign mistress of true melancholy,
The poisonous damp of night dispunge upon me,
That life, a very rebel to my will,
May hang no longer on me. Throw my heart
Against the flint and hardness of my fault,
Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder
And finish all foul thoughts. O Antony,
Nobler than my revolt is infamous,
Forgive me in thine own particular,
But let the world rank me in register
A master-leaver and a fugitive.
O Antony! O Antony!

sp.speaker: FIRST WATCH
sp.l: Let’s speak to him.

sp.speaker: SENTRY
sp.p:
Let’s hear him, for the things he speaks may
concern Caesar.

sp.speaker: SECOND WATCH
sp.l: Let’s do so. But he sleeps.

sp.speaker: SENTRY
sp.l: Swoons rather, for so bad a prayer as his
Was never yet for sleep.

sp.speaker: FIRST WATCH
sp.l: Go we to him.

sp.speaker: SECOND WATCH
sp.l: Awake, sir, awake! Speak to us.

sp.speaker: FIRST WATCH
sp.l: Hear you, sir?

sp.speaker: SENTRY
sp.l: The hand of death hath raught him.
Hark, the drums
Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him
To th’ court of guard; he is of note. Our hour
Is fully out.

sp.speaker: SECOND WATCH
sp.l: Come on then. He may recover yet.

div.head: Scene 10
div.stage: Enter Antony and Scarus, with their army.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Their preparation is today by sea;
We please them not by land.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: For both, my lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I would they’d fight i’ th’ fire or i’ th’ air;
We’d fight there too. But this it is: our foot
Upon the hills adjoining to the city
Shall stay with us— order for sea is given;
They have put forth the haven—
Where their appointment we may best discover
And look on their endeavor.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: But being charged, we will be still by land—
Which, as I take ’t, we shall, for his best force
Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales,
And hold our best advantage.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Yet they are not joined. Where yond pine does stand,
I shall discover all. I’ll bring thee word
Straight how ’tis like to go.

stage.stage: Alarum afar off, as at a sea fight.

sp.speaker: SCARUS
sp.l: Swallows have built
In Cleopatra’s sails their nests. The augurs
Say they know not, they cannot tell, look grimly
And dare not speak their knowledge. Antony
Is valiant and dejected, and by starts
His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear
Of what he has and has not.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: All is lost!
This foul Egyptian hath betrayèd me.
My fleet hath yielded to the foe, and yonder
They cast their caps up and carouse together
Like friends long lost. Triple-turned whore! ’Tis thou
Hast sold me to this novice, and my heart
Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly—
For when I am revenged upon my charm,
I have done all. Bid them all fly. Begone!
O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more.
Fortune and Antony part here; even here
Do we shake hands. All come to this? The hearts
That spanieled me at heels, to whom I gave
Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets
On blossoming Caesar, and this pine is barked
That overtopped them all. Betrayed I am.
O, this false soul of Egypt! This grave charm,
Whose eye becked forth my wars and called them home,
Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end,
Like a right gypsy hath at fast and loose
Beguiled me to the very heart of loss.—
What Eros, Eros!
Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Why is my lord enraged against his love?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving
And blemish Caesar’s triumph. Let him take thee
And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians!
Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot
Of all thy sex; most monster-like be shown
For poor’st diminutives, for dolts, and let
Patient Octavia plow thy visage up
With her preparèd nails.
’Tis well th’ art gone,
If it be well to live. But better ’twere
Thou fell’st into my fury, for one death
Might have prevented many.— Eros, ho!—
The shirt of Nessus is upon me. Teach me,
Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage.
Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o’ th’ moon,
And with those hands that grasped the heaviest club
Subdue my worthiest self. The witch shall die.
To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall
Under this plot. She dies for ’t.— Eros, ho!

div.head: Scene 13
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra, Charmian, Iras, and Mardian.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Help me, my women! O, he’s more mad
Than Telamon for his shield; the boar of Thessaly
Was never so embossed.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: To th’ monument!
There lock yourself and send him word you are dead.
The soul and body rive not more in parting
Than greatness going off.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: To th’ monument!—
Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself.
Say that the last I spoke was “ Antony,”
And word it, prithee, piteously. Hence, Mardian,
And bring me how he takes my death.— To th’ monument!

div.head: Scene 14

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Eros, thou yet behold’st me?

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Ay, noble lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Sometime we see a cloud that’s dragonish,
A vapor sometime like a bear or lion,
A towered citadel, a pendent rock,
A forkèd mountain, or blue promontory
With trees upon ’t that nod unto the world
And mock our eyes with air. Thou hast seen these signs.
They are black vesper’s pageants.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: That which is now a horse, even with a thought
The rack dislimns and makes it indistinct
As water is in water.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: It does, my lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is
Even such a body. Here I am Antony,
Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.
I made these wars for Egypt, and the Queen,
Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine—
Which whilst it was mine had annexed unto ’t
A million more, now lost— she, Eros, has
Packed cards with Caesar and false-played my glory
Unto an enemy’s triumph.
Nay, weep not, gentle Eros. There is left us
Ourselves to end ourselves.
O, thy vile lady!
She has robbed me of my sword.

sp.speaker: MARDIAN
sp.l: No, Antony,
My mistress loved thee and her fortunes mingled
With thine entirely.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Hence, saucy eunuch! Peace!
She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.

sp.speaker: MARDIAN
sp.l: Death of one person can be paid but once,
And that she has discharged. What thou wouldst do
Is done unto thy hand. The last she spake
Was “ Antony, most noble Antony.”
Then in the midst a tearing groan did break
The name of Antony; it was divided
Between her heart and lips. She rendered life
Thy name so buried in her.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Dead, then?

sp.speaker: MARDIAN
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Unarm, Eros. The long day’s task is done,
And we must sleep.— That thou depart’st hence safe
Does pay thy labor richly. Go.
Off, pluck off!
sp.stage: Eros begins to remove Antony’s armor.
sp.l: The sevenfold shield of Ajax cannot keep
The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides!
Heart, once be stronger than thy continent;
Crack thy frail case. Apace, Eros, apace!
No more a soldier. Bruisèd pieces, go.
You have been nobly borne.— From me awhile.
I will o’ertake thee, Cleopatra, and
Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now
All length is torture. Since the torch is out,
Lie down and stray no farther. Now all labor
Mars what it does; yea, very force entangles
Itself with strength. Seal, then, and all is done.—
Eros!— I come, my queen.— Eros!— Stay for me.
Where souls do couch on flowers, we’ll hand in hand,
And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze.
Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops,
And all the haunt be ours.— Come, Eros, Eros!

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: What would my lord?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Since Cleopatra died
I have lived in such dishonor that the gods
Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword
Quartered the world and o’er green Neptune’s back
With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack
The courage of a woman— less noble mind
Than she which, by her death, our Caesar tells
“ I am conqueror of myself.” Thou art sworn, Eros,
That when the exigent should come, which now
Is come indeed, when I should see behind me
Th’ inevitable prosecution of
Disgrace and horror, that on my command
Thou then wouldst kill me. Do ’t. The time is come.
Thou strik’st not me; ’tis Caesar thou defeat’st.
Put color in thy cheek.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: The gods withhold me!
Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts,
Though enemy, lost aim and could not?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Eros,
Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome and see
Thy master thus with pleached arms, bending down
His corrigible neck, his face subdued
To penetrative shame, whilst the wheeled seat
Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded
His baseness that ensued?

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: I would not see ’t.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Come, then, for with a wound I must be cured.
Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn
Most useful for thy country.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: O, sir, pardon me!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: When I did make thee free, swor’st thou not then
To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once,
Or thy precedent services are all
But accidents unpurposed. Draw, and come.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Turn from me then that noble countenance
Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Lo thee!

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: My sword is drawn.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Then let it do at once
The thing why thou hast drawn it.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: My dear master,
My captain, and my emperor, let me say,
Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: ’Tis said, man, and farewell.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Now, Eros.

sp.speaker: EROS
sp.l: Why, there, then.
Thus I do escape the sorrow
Of Antony’s death.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Thrice nobler than myself,
Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what
I should and thou couldst not. My queen and Eros
Have by their brave instruction got upon me
A nobleness in record. But I will be
A bridegroom in my death and run into ’t
As to a lover’s bed. Come then, and, Eros,
Thy master dies thy scholar. To do thus
I learned of thee. He stabs himself. How, not dead? Not dead?
The guard, ho! O, dispatch me!

div.stage: Enter a company of the Guard, one of them named Dercetus.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: What’s the noise?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I have done my work ill, friends. O, make an end
Of what I have begun!

sp.speaker: SECOND GUARD
sp.l: The star is fall’n.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: And time is at his period.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Alas, and woe!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Let him that loves me strike me dead.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: SECOND GUARD
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: THIRD GUARD
sp.l: Nor anyone.

div.stage: All but Antony and Dercetus exit.

sp.speaker: DERCETUS
sp.l: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
This sword but shown to Caesar with this tidings
Shall enter me with him.

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Where’s Antony?

sp.speaker: DERCETUS
sp.l: There, Diomed, there.

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Lives he? Wilt thou not answer, man?

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword, and give me
Sufficing strokes for death.

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Most absolute lord,
My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: When did she send thee?

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Now, my lord.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: Locked in her monument. She had a prophesying fear
Of what hath come to pass. For when she saw—
Which never shall be found— you did suspect
She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage
Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead;
But fearing since how it might work, hath sent
Me to proclaim the truth, and I am come,
I dread, too late.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Too late, good Diomed. Call my guard, I prithee.

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: What ho! The Emperor’s guard! The guard, what ho!
Come, your lord calls.

div.stage: Enter four or five of the Guard of Antony.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides.
’Tis the last service that I shall command you.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear
All your true followers out.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Most heavy day!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate
To grace it with your sorrows. Bid that welcome
Which comes to punish us, and we punish it,
Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up.
I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends,
And have my thanks for all.

div.stage: They exit bearing Antony and the body of Eros.

div.head: Scene 15
div.stage: Enter Cleopatra and her maids aloft, with Charmian and Iras.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Be comforted, dear madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: No, I will not.
All strange and terrible events are welcome,
But comforts we despise. Our size of sorrow,
Proportioned to our cause, must be as great
As that which makes it.
How now? Is he dead?

sp.speaker: DIOMEDES
sp.l: His death’s upon him, but not dead.
Look out o’ th’ other side your monument.
His guard have brought him thither.

div.stage: Enter Antony below, and the Guard bearing him.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O sun,
Burn the great sphere thou mov’st in. Darkling stand
The varying shore o’ th’ world! O Antony, Antony,
Antony! Help, Charmian! Help, Iras, help!
Help, friends below! Let’s draw him hither.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Peace!
Not Caesar’s valor hath o’erthrown Antony,
But Antony’s hath triumphed on itself.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: So it should be that none but Antony
Should conquer Antony, but woe ’tis so!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I am dying, Egypt, dying. Only
I here importune death awhile until
Of many thousand kisses the poor last
I lay upon thy lips.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I dare not, dear,
Dear my lord, pardon, I dare not,
Lest I be taken. Not th’ imperious show
Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall
Be brooched with me; if knife, drugs, serpents have
Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe.
Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes
And still conclusion, shall acquire no honor
Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony.—
Help me, my women!— We must draw thee up.—
Assist, good friends.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: O, quick, or I am gone.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Here’s sport indeed. How heavy weighs my lord!
Our strength is all gone into heaviness;
That makes the weight. Had I great Juno’s power,
The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up
And set thee by Jove’s side. Yet come a little.
Wishers were ever fools. O, come, come, come!
sp.stage: They heave Antony aloft to Cleopatra.
sp.l: And welcome, welcome! Die when thou hast lived;
Quicken with kissing. Had my lips that power,
Thus would I wear them out.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: A heavy sight!

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: I am dying, Egypt, dying.
Give me some wine, and let me speak a little.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: No, let me speak, and let me rail so high
That the false huswife Fortune break her wheel,
Provoked by my offense.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: One word, sweet queen:
Of Caesar seek your honor with your safety— O!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: They do not go together.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: Gentle, hear me.
None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: My resolution and my hands I’ll trust,
None about Caesar.

sp.speaker: ANTONY
sp.l: The miserable change now at my end
Lament nor sorrow at, but please your thoughts
In feeding them with those my former fortunes
Wherein I lived the greatest prince o’ th’ world,
The noblest, and do now not basely die,
Not cowardly put off my helmet to
My countryman— a Roman by a Roman
Valiantly vanquished. Now my spirit is going;
I can no more.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Noblest of men, woo’t die?
Hast thou no care of me? Shall I abide
In this dull world, which in thy absence is
No better than a sty? O see, my women,
The crown o’ th’ Earth doth melt.— My lord!
O, withered is the garland of the war;
The soldier’s pole is fall’n; young boys and girls
Are level now with men. The odds is gone,
And there is nothing left remarkable
Beneath the visiting moon.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: O, quietness, lady!

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: She’s dead, too, our sovereign.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Lady!

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: O madam, madam, madam!

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: Royal Egypt! Empress!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Peace, peace, Iras!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: No more but e’en a woman, and commanded
By such poor passion as the maid that milks
And does the meanest chares. It were for me
To throw my scepter at the injurious gods,
To tell them that this world did equal theirs
Till they had stolen our jewel. All’s but naught.
Patience is sottish, and impatience does
Become a dog that’s mad. Then is it sin
To rush into the secret house of death
Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women?
What, what, good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian?
My noble girls! Ah, women, women! Look,
Our lamp is spent; it’s out. Good sirs, take heart.
We’ll bury him; and then, what’s brave, what’s noble,
Let’s do ’t after the high Roman fashion
And make death proud to take us. Come, away.
This case of that huge spirit now is cold.
Ah women, women! Come, we have no friend
But resolution and the briefest end.

div.stage: They exit, bearing off Antony’s body.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Caesar with Agrippa, Dolabella, Maecenas, Gallus, and Proculeius, his council of war.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield.
Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks
The pauses that he makes.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Caesar, I shall.

div.stage: Enter Dercetus with the sword of Antony.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar’st
Appear thus to us?

sp.speaker: DERCETUS
sp.l: I am called Dercetus.
Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy
Best to be served. Whilst he stood up and spoke,
He was my master, and I wore my life
To spend upon his haters. If thou please
To take me to thee, as I was to him
I’ll be to Caesar; if thou pleasest not,
I yield thee up my life.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: What is ’t thou say’st?

sp.speaker: DERCETUS
sp.l: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: The breaking of so great a thing should make
A greater crack. The round world
Should have shook lions into civil streets
And citizens to their dens. The death of Antony
Is not a single doom; in the name lay
A moiety of the world.

sp.speaker: DERCETUS
sp.l: He is dead, Caesar,
Not by a public minister of justice,
Nor by a hirèd knife, but that self hand
Which writ his honor in the acts it did
Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it,
Splitted the heart. This is his sword.
I robbed his wound of it. Behold it stained
With his most noble blood.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Look you sad, friends?
The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings
To wash the eyes of kings.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: And strange it is
That nature must compel us to lament
Our most persisted deeds.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: His taints and honors
Waged equal with him.

sp.speaker: AGRIPPA
sp.l: A rarer spirit never
Did steer humanity, but you gods will give us
Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touched.

sp.speaker: MAECENAS
sp.l: When such a spacious mirror’s set before him,
He needs must see himself.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: O Antony,
I have followed thee to this, but we do lance
Diseases in our bodies. I must perforce
Have shown to thee such a declining day
Or look on thine. We could not stall together
In the whole world. But yet let me lament
With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts
That thou my brother, my competitor
In top of all design, my mate in empire,
Friend and companion in the front of war,
The arm of mine own body, and the heart
Where mine his thoughts did kindle— that our stars
Unreconciliable should divide
Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends—
But I will tell you at some meeter season.
The business of this man looks out of him.
We’ll hear him what he says.— Whence are you?

sp.speaker: EGYPTIAN
sp.l: A poor Egyptian yet, the Queen my mistress,
Confined in all she has, her monument,
Of thy intents desires instruction,
That she preparedly may frame herself
To th’ way she’s forced to.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Bid her have good heart.
She soon shall know of us, by some of ours,
How honorable and how kindly we
Determine for her. For Caesar cannot live
To be ungentle.

sp.speaker: EGYPTIAN
sp.l: So the gods preserve thee.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say
We purpose her no shame. Give her what comforts
The quality of her passion shall require,
Lest, in her greatness, by some mortal stroke
She do defeat us, for her life in Rome
Would be eternal in our triumph. Go,
And with your speediest bring us what she says
And how you find of her.

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: Caesar, I shall.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Gallus, go you along.
Where’s Dolabella,
To second Proculeius?

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Dolabella!

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Let him alone, for I remember now
How he’s employed. He shall in time be ready.
Go with me to my tent, where you shall see
How hardly I was drawn into this war,
How calm and gentle I proceeded still
In all my writings. Go with me and see
What I can show in this.

div.head: Scene 2

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: My desolation does begin to make
A better life. ’Tis paltry to be Caesar;
Not being Fortune, he’s but Fortune’s knave,
A minister of her will. And it is great
To do that thing that ends all other deeds,
Which shackles accidents and bolts up change,
Which sleeps and never palates more the dung,
The beggar’s nurse, and Caesar’s.

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt,
And bids thee study on what fair demands
Thou mean’st to have him grant thee.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What’s thy name?

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: My name is Proculeius.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Antony
Did tell me of you, bade me trust you, but
I do not greatly care to be deceived
That have no use for trusting. If your master
Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him
That majesty, to keep decorum, must
No less beg than a kingdom. If he please
To give me conquered Egypt for my son,
He gives me so much of mine own as I
Will kneel to him with thanks.

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: Be of good cheer.
You’re fall’n into a princely hand; fear nothing.
Make your full reference freely to my lord,
Who is so full of grace that it flows over
On all that need. Let me report to him
Your sweet dependency, and you shall find
A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness
Where he for grace is kneeled to.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Pray you tell him
I am his fortune’s vassal and I send him
The greatness he has got. I hourly learn
A doctrine of obedience, and would gladly
Look him i’ th’ face.

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: This I’ll report, dear lady.
Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied
Of him that caused it.

div.stage: Gallus and Soldiers enter and seize Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: GALLUS
sp.l: You see how easily she may be surprised.
Guard her till Caesar come.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: Royal queen!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: O, Cleopatra, thou art taken, queen!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Quick, quick, good hands!

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: Hold, worthy lady, hold!
Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this
Relieved, but not betrayed.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What, of death, too,
That rids our dogs of languish?

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: Cleopatra,
Do not abuse my master’s bounty by
Th’ undoing of yourself. Let the world see
His nobleness well acted, which your death
Will never let come forth.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Where art thou, Death?
Come hither, come! Come, come, and take a queen
Worth many babes and beggars.

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: O, temperance, lady!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Sir, I will eat no meat; I’ll not drink, sir.
If idle talk will once be necessary—
I’ll not sleep neither. This mortal house I’ll ruin,
Do Caesar what he can. Know, sir, that I
Will not wait pinioned at your master’s court,
Nor once be chastised with the sober eye
Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up
And show me to the shouting varletry
Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt
Be gentle grave unto me; rather on Nilus’ mud
Lay me stark naked, and let the waterflies
Blow me into abhorring; rather make
My country’s high pyramides my gibbet
And hang me up in chains!

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: You do extend
These thoughts of horror further than you shall
Find cause in Caesar.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Proculeius,
What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows,
And he hath sent for thee. For the Queen,
I’ll take her to my guard.

sp.speaker: PROCULEIUS
sp.l: So, Dolabella,
It shall content me best. Be gentle to her.
To Cleopatra. To Caesar I will speak what you shall please,
If you’ll employ me to him.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Say I would die.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Most noble empress, you have heard of me.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Assuredly you know me.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: No matter, sir, what I have heard or known.
You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams;
Is ’t not your trick?

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: I understand not, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I dreamt there was an emperor Antony.
O, such another sleep, that I might see
But such another man.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: If it might please you—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: His face was as the heavens, and therein stuck
A sun and moon, which kept their course and lighted
The little O, the Earth.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Most sovereign creature—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: His legs bestrid the ocean, his reared arm
Crested the world. His voice was propertied
As all the tunèd spheres, and that to friends;
But when he meant to quail and shake the orb,
He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty,
There was no winter in ’t; an autumn ’twas
That grew the more by reaping. His delights
Were dolphin-like; they showed his back above
The element they lived in. In his livery
Walked crowns and crownets; realms and islands were
As plates dropped from his pocket.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Cleopatra—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Think you there was, or might be, such a man
As this I dreamt of?

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Gentle madam, no.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: You lie up to the hearing of the gods!
But if there be nor ever were one such,
It’s past the size of dreaming. Nature wants stuff
To vie strange forms with fancy, yet t’ imagine
An Antony were nature’s piece ’gainst fancy,
Condemning shadows quite.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Hear me, good madam.
Your loss is as yourself, great; and you bear it
As answering to the weight. Would I might never
O’ertake pursued success but I do feel,
By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites
My very heart at root.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: I thank you, sir.
Know you what Caesar means to do with me?

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Nay, pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Though he be honorable—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: He’ll lead me, then, in triumph.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Madam, he will. I know ’t.

div.stage: Flourish. Enter Caesar, Proculeius, Gallus, Maecenas, and others of his train.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Make way there! Caesar!

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Which is the Queen of Egypt?

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: It is the Emperor, madam.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Arise. You shall not kneel.
I pray you, rise. Rise, Egypt.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Sir, the gods
Will have it thus. My master and my lord
I must obey.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Take to you no hard thoughts.
The record of what injuries you did us,
Though written in our flesh, we shall remember
As things but done by chance.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Sole sir o’ th’ world,
I cannot project mine own cause so well
To make it clear, but do confess I have
Been laden with like frailties which before
Have often shamed our sex.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Cleopatra, know
We will extenuate rather than enforce.
If you apply yourself to our intents,
Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find
A benefit in this change; but if you seek
To lay on me a cruelty by taking
Antony’s course, you shall bereave yourself
Of my good purposes, and put your children
To that destruction which I’ll guard them from
If thereon you rely. I’ll take my leave.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: And may through all the world. ’Tis yours, and we,
Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall
Hang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels
I am possessed of. ’Tis exactly valued,
Not petty things admitted.— Where’s Seleucus?

sp.speaker: SELEUCUS
sp.l: Here, madam.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: This is my treasurer. Let him speak, my lord,
Upon his peril, that I have reserved
To myself nothing.— Speak the truth, Seleucus.

sp.speaker: SELEUCUS
sp.l: Madam, I had rather seel my lips
Than to my peril speak that which is not.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: What have I kept back?

sp.speaker: SELEUCUS
sp.l: Enough to purchase what you have made known.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Nay, blush not, Cleopatra. I approve
Your wisdom in the deed.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: See, Caesar, O, behold
How pomp is followed! Mine will now be yours,
And should we shift estates, yours would be mine.
The ingratitude of this Seleucus does
Even make me wild.— O slave, of no more trust
Than love that’s hired! What, goest thou back? Thou shalt
Go back, I warrant thee! But I’ll catch thine eyes
Though they had wings. Slave, soulless villain, dog!
O rarely base!

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Good queen, let us entreat you—

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this,
That thou vouchsafing here to visit me,
Doing the honor of thy lordliness
To one so meek, that mine own servant should
Parcel the sum of my disgraces by
Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar,
That I some lady trifles have reserved,
Immoment toys, things of such dignity
As we greet modern friends withal, and say
Some nobler token I have kept apart
For Livia and Octavia, to induce
Their mediation, must I be unfolded
With one that I have bred? The gods! It smites me
Beneath the fall I have. To Seleucus. Prithee, go hence,
Or I shall show the cinders of my spirits
Through th’ ashes of my chance. Wert thou a man,
Thou wouldst have mercy on me.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Forbear, Seleucus.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Be it known that we, the greatest, are misthought
For things that others do; and when we fall,
We answer others’ merits in our name—
Are therefore to be pitied.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Cleopatra,
Not what you have reserved nor what acknowledged
Put we i’ th’ roll of conquest. Still be ’t yours!
Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe
Caesar’s no merchant to make prize with you
Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheered.
Make not your thoughts your prisons. No, dear queen,
For we intend so to dispose you as
Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed and sleep.
Our care and pity is so much upon you
That we remain your friend. And so adieu.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: My master and my lord!

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Not so. Adieu.

div.stage: Flourish. Caesar and his train exit.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: He words me, girls, he words me, that I should not
Be noble to myself. But hark thee, Charmian.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: Finish, good lady. The bright day is done,
And we are for the dark.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Hie thee again.
I have spoke already, and it is provided.
Go put it to the haste.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Where’s the Queen?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Behold, sir.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Dolabella.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Madam, as thereto sworn by your command,
Which my love makes religion to obey,
I tell you this: Caesar through Syria
Intends his journey, and within three days
You with your children will he send before.
Make your best use of this. I have performed
Your pleasure and my promise.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Dolabella,
I shall remain your debtor.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: I your servant.
Adieu, good queen. I must attend on Caesar.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Farewell, and thanks.
Now, Iras, what think’st thou?
Thou an Egyptian puppet shall be shown
In Rome as well as I. Mechanic slaves
With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers shall
Uplift us to the view. In their thick breaths,
Rank of gross diet, shall we be enclouded
And forced to drink their vapor.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: The gods forbid!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Nay, ’tis most certain, Iras. Saucy lictors
Will catch at us like strumpets, and scald rhymers
Ballad us out o’ tune. The quick comedians
Extemporally will stage us and present
Our Alexandrian revels. Antony
Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see
Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness
I’ th’ posture of a whore.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: O the good gods!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Nay, that’s certain.

sp.speaker: IRAS
sp.l: I’ll never see ’t! For I am sure mine nails
Are stronger than mine eyes.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Why, that’s the way
To fool their preparation and to conquer
Their most absurd intents.
Now, Charmian!
Show me, my women, like a queen. Go fetch
My best attires. I am again for Cydnus
To meet Mark Antony. Sirrah Iras, go.—
Now, noble Charmian, we’ll dispatch indeed,
And when thou hast done this chare, I’ll give thee leave
To play till Doomsday.— Bring our crown and all.
Wherefore’s this noise?

sp.speaker: GUARDSMAN
sp.l: Here is a rural fellow
That will not be denied your Highness’ presence.
He brings you figs.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Let him come in.
What poor an instrument
