May do a noble deed! He brings me liberty.
My resolution’s placed, and I have nothing
Of woman in me. Now from head to foot
I am marble-constant. Now the fleeting moon
No planet is of mine.

div.stage: Enter Guardsman and Countryman, with a basket.

sp.speaker: GUARDSMAN
sp.l: This is the man.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Avoid, and leave him.
Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there
That kills and pains not?

sp.speaker: COUNTRYMAN
sp.p:
Truly I have him, but I would not be
the party that should desire you to touch him, for
his biting is immortal. Those that do die of it do
seldom or never recover.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Remember’st thou any that have died on ’t?

sp.speaker: COUNTRYMAN
sp.p:
Very many, men and women too. I
heard of one of them no longer than yesterday— a
very honest woman, but something given to lie, as a
woman should not do but in the way of honesty—
how she died of the biting of it, what pain she felt.
Truly, she makes a very good report o’ th’ worm.
But he that will believe all that they say shall never
be saved by half that they do. But this is most
falliable, the worm’s an odd worm.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Get thee hence. Farewell.

sp.speaker: COUNTRYMAN
sp.p: I wish you all joy of the worm.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: COUNTRYMAN
sp.p:
You must think this, look you, that the
worm will do his kind.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Ay, ay, farewell.

sp.speaker: COUNTRYMAN
sp.p:
Look you, the worm is not to be trusted
but in the keeping of wise people, for indeed there
is no goodness in the worm.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Take thou no care; it shall be heeded.

sp.speaker: COUNTRYMAN
sp.p:
Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you,
for it is not worth the feeding.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Will it eat me?

sp.speaker: COUNTRYMAN
sp.p:
You must not think I am so simple but
I know the devil himself will not eat a woman. I
know that a woman is a dish for the gods if the devil
dress her not. But truly these same whoreson devils
do the gods great harm in their women, for in every
ten that they make, the devils mar five.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.p: Well, get thee gone. Farewell.

sp.speaker: COUNTRYMAN
sp.p:
Yes, forsooth. I wish you joy o’ th’
worm.

div.stage: Enter Iras bearing Cleopatra’s royal regalia.

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Give me my robe. Put on my crown. I have
Immortal longings in me. Now no more
The juice of Egypt’s grape shall moist this lip.
sp.stage: Charmian and Iras begin to dress her.
sp.l: Yare, yare, good Iras, quick. Methinks I hear
Antony call. I see him rouse himself
To praise my noble act. I hear him mock
The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men
To excuse their after wrath.— Husband, I come!
Now to that name my courage prove my title.
I am fire and air; my other elements
I give to baser life.— So, have you done?
Come then, and take the last warmth of my lips.
Farewell, kind Charmian.— Iras, long farewell.
sp.stage: She kisses them. Iras falls and dies.
sp.l: Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall?
If thou and nature can so gently part,
The stroke of death is as a lover’s pinch,
Which hurts and is desired. Dost thou lie still?
If thus thou vanishest, thou tell’st the world
It is not worth leave-taking.

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may say
The gods themselves do weep!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: This proves me base.
If she first meet the curlèd Antony,
He’ll make demand of her, and spend that kiss
Which is my heaven to have.— Come, thou mortal wretch,
sp.stage: She places an asp on her breast.
sp.l: With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate
Of life at once untie. Poor venomous fool,
Be angry and dispatch. O, couldst thou speak,
That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass
Unpolicied!

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: O eastern star!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: Peace, peace!
Dost thou not see my baby at my breast,
That sucks the nurse asleep?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: O, break! O, break!

sp.speaker: CLEOPATRA
sp.l: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle—
O Antony!— Nay, I will take thee too.
sp.stage: She places an asp on her arm.
sp.l: What should I stay—

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: In this wild world? So, fare thee well.
Now boast thee, Death, in thy possession lies
A lass unparalleled. Downy windows, close,
And golden Phoebus, never be beheld
Of eyes again so royal. Your crown’s awry.
I’ll mend it, and then play—

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: Where’s the Queen?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Speak softly. Wake her not.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: Caesar hath sent—

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: Too slow a messenger.
O, come apace, dispatch! I partly feel thee.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: Approach, ho! All’s not well. Caesar’s beguiled.

sp.speaker: SECOND GUARD
sp.l: There’s Dolabella sent from Caesar. Call him.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: What work is here, Charmian? Is this well done?

sp.speaker: CHARMIAN
sp.l: It is well done, and fitting for a princess
Descended of so many royal kings.
Ah, soldier!

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: How goes it here?

sp.speaker: SECOND GUARD
sp.l: All dead.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Caesar, thy thoughts
Touch their effects in this. Thyself art coming
To see performed the dreaded act which thou
So sought’st to hinder.

div.stage: Enter Caesar and all his train, marching.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: A way there, a way for Caesar!

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: O sir, you are too sure an augurer:
That you did fear is done.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Bravest at the last,
She leveled at our purposes and, being royal,
Took her own way. The manner of their deaths?
I do not see them bleed.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Who was last with them?

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: A simple countryman that brought her figs.
This was his basket.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Poisoned, then.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: O Caesar,
This Charmian lived but now; she stood and spake.
I found her trimming up the diadem
On her dead mistress; tremblingly she stood,
And on the sudden dropped.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: O, noble weakness!
If they had swallowed poison, ’twould appear
By external swelling; but she looks like sleep,
As she would catch another Antony
In her strong toil of grace.

sp.speaker: DOLABELLA
sp.l: Here on her breast
There is a vent of blood, and something blown.
The like is on her arm.

sp.speaker: FIRST GUARD
sp.l: This is an aspic’s trail, and these fig leaves
Have slime upon them, such as th’ aspic leaves
Upon the caves of Nile.

sp.speaker: CAESAR
sp.l: Most probable
That so she died, for her physician tells me
She hath pursued conclusions infinite
Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed,
And bear her women from the monument.
She shall be buried by her Antony.
No grave upon the earth shall clip in it
A pair so famous. High events as these
Strike those that make them; and their story is
No less in pity than his glory which
Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall
In solemn show attend this funeral,
And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see
High order in this great solemnity.

div.stage: They all exit, the Guards bearing the dead bodies.
